question:
Please refer to the summary above to answer this question
A medical student is examining the table in the abstract. She notices that the standard error surrounding measurements in the pulmharkimab 150 mg/day group is generally greater than the standard errors for the placebo and pulmharkimab 75 mg/day groups. Which of the following statements is the best explanation for the increased standard error in the pulmharkimab 150 mg/day group?"
"Impact of pulmharkimab on asthma control and cardiovascular disease progression in patients with coronary artery disease and comorbid asthma
Introduction:
Active asthma has been found to be associated with a more than two-fold increase in the risk of myocardial infarction, even after adjusting for cardiovascular risk factors. It has been suggested that the inflammatory mediators and accelerated atherosclerosis characterizing systemic inflammation may increase the risk of both asthma and cardiovascular disease. This study evaluated the efficacy of the novel IL-1 inhibitor pulmharkimab in improving asthma and cardiovascular disease progression.
Methods:
In this double-blind, randomized controlled trial, patients (N=1200) with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction in the past 2 years, and a diagnosis of comorbid adult-onset asthma were recruited from cardiology clinics at a large academic medical center in Philadelphia, PA. Patients who were immunocompromised or had a history of recurrent infections were excluded.
Patients were subsequently randomly assigned a 12-month course of pulmharkimab 75 mg/day, pulmharkimab 150 mg/day, or a placebo, with each group containing 400 participants. All participants were included in analysis and analyzed in the groups to which they were randomized regardless of medication adherence. Variables measured included plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ) scores, which quantified the severity of asthma symptoms. Plaque volume was determined by ultrasound.
Analyses were performed from baseline to month 12.
Results:
At baseline, participants in the two groups did not differ by age, gender, race, plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores (p > 0.05 for all). A total of 215 participants (18%) were lost to follow-up. At 12-month follow-up, the groups contained the following numbers of participants:
Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d: 388 participants
Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d: 202 participants
Placebo: 395 participants
Table 1: Association between pulmharkimab and both pulmonary and cardiovascular outcomes. Models were adjusted for sociodemographic variables and medical comorbidities. All outcome variables were approximately normally distributed.
Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d, (Mean +/- 2 SE) Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d, (Mean +/- 2 SE) Placebo, (Mean +/- 2 SE) P-value
Plaque volume (mm3), change from baseline 6.6 ± 2.8 1.2 ± 4.7 15.8 ± 2.9 < 0.01
LDL-C levels, change from baseline -9.4 ± 3.6 -11.2 ± 14.3 -8.4 ± 3.9 0.28
FEV1/FVC ratio, change from baseline 0.29 ± 2.21 0.34 ± 5.54 -0.22 ± 3.21 0.27
ACQ scores, change from baseline 0.31 ± 1.22 0.46 ± 3.25 0.12 ± 1.33 0.43
Conclusion:
Pulmharkimab may be effective in reducing plaque volume but does not lead to improved asthma control in patients with a history of myocardial infarction and comorbid asthma.
Source of funding: Southeast Institute for Advanced Lung and Cardiovascular Studies, American Center for Advancement of Cardiovascular Health"
A) It indicates an increased likelihood of bias
B) It indicates decreased external validity
C) It indicates a lack of statistical significance
D) It reflects a smaller sample size
E) It indicates more narrow confidence intervals
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A medical student is examining the table in the abstract. She notices that the standard error surrounding measurements in the <fact1>pulmharkimab 150 mg/day group</fact1> is generally greater than the standard errors for the <fact2>placebo</fact2> and <fact3>pulmharkimab 75 mg/day groups</fact3>. Which of the following statements is the best explanation for the increased standard error in the <fact1>pulmharkimab 150 mg/day group</fact1>?

"Impact of pulmharkimab on asthma control and cardiovascular disease progression in patients with coronary artery disease and comorbid asthma
Introduction:

It has been suggested that the inflammatory mediators and accelerated atherosclerosis characterizing systemic inflammation may increase the risk of both asthma and cardiovascular disease. This study evaluated the efficacy of the novel IL-1 inhibitor pulmharkimab in improving asthma and cardiovascular disease progression.
Methods:
In this double-blind, randomized controlled trial, patients (N=1200) with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction in the past 2 years, and a diagnosis of comorbid adult-onset asthma were recruited from cardiology clinics at a large academic medical center in Philadelphia, PA. Patients who were immunocompromised or had a history of recurrent infections were excluded.
Patients were subsequently randomly assigned a 12-month course of <fact1>pulmharkimab 75 mg/day</fact1>, <fact1>pulmharkimab 150 mg/day</fact1>, or a <fact2>placebo</fact2>, with each group containing 400 participants. All participants were included in analysis and analyzed in the groups to which they were randomized regardless of medication adherence. Variables measured included plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ) scores, which quantified the severity of asthma symptoms. Plaque volume was determined by ultrasound.
Analyses were performed from baseline to month 12.
Results:
At baseline, participants in the two groups did not differ by age, gender, race, plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores (p > 0.05 for all). A total of 215 participants (18%) were lost to follow-up. At 12-month follow-up, the groups contained the following numbers of participants:
<fact3>Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d: 388 participants</fact3>
<fact1>Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d: 202 participants</fact1>
<fact2>Placebo: 395 participants</fact2>
Table 1: Association between pulmharkimab and both pulmonary and cardiovascular outcomes. Models were adjusted for sociodemographic variables and medical comorbidities. All outcome variables were approximately normally distributed.
<fact1>Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d, (Mean +/- 2 SE)</fact1> <fact1>Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d, (Mean +/- 2 SE)</fact1> <fact2>Placebo, (Mean +/- 2 SE)</fact2> P-value
Plaque volume (mm3), change from baseline 6.6 ± 2.8 1.2 ± 4.7 15.8 ± 2.9 < 0.01
LDL-C levels, change from baseline -9.4 ± 3.6 -11.2 ± 14.3 -8.4 ± 3.9 0.28
FEV1/FVC ratio, change from baseline 0.29 ± 2.21 0.34 ± 5.54 -0.22 ± 3.21 0.27
ACQ scores, change from baseline 0.31 ± 1.22 0.46 ± 3.25 0.12 ± 1.33 0.43
Conclusion:
Pulmharkimab may be effective in reducing plaque volume but does not lead to improved asthma control in patients with a history of myocardial infarction and comorbid asthma.
Source of funding: Southeast Institute for Advanced Lung and Cardiovascular Studies, American Center for Advancement of Cardiovascular Health

Answer: D) It reflects a smaller sample size

Explanation: 
The increased standard error in the <fact1>pulmharkimab 150 mg/day group</fact1> can be attributed to the smaller sample size of this group. As shown in the results, the <fact1>pulmharkimab 150 mg/day group</fact1> had only 202 participants at 12-month follow-up, compared to 388 participants in the <fact3>pulmharkimab 75 mg/day group</fact3> and 395 participants in the <fact2>placebo group</fact2>. This smaller sample size would lead to a larger standard error, as the standard error is inversely proportional to the square root of the sample size.

answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A cardiologist at another institution is trying to replicate the table in the abstract with a very similar study that he is conducting. After collecting data on changes in <fact1>plaque volume</fact1>, <fact2>LDL-C levels</fact2>, <fact3>FEV1/FVC ratio</fact3>, and <fact4>ACQ scores</fact4> from baseline to 12-month follow-up, he is curious if the changes in the aforementioned measurements are statistically significant. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical method to compare the groups?"

Answer: 
The most appropriate statistical method to compare the groups would be to use <fact5>Analysis of variance (ANOVA)</fact5>. This is because the cardiologist is comparing the means of more than two groups (pulmharkimab 75 mg/d, pulmharkimab 150 mg/d, and placebo) to determine if there are any statistically significant differences between them. The outcome variables (<fact1>plaque volume</fact1>, <fact2>LDL-C levels</fact2>, <fact3>FEV1/FVC ratio</fact3>, and <fact4>ACQ scores</fact4>) are approximately normally distributed, which is a requirement for ANOVA.

question:
Background:
Some patients with severe asthma have frequent exacerbations associated with persistent eosinophilic inflammation despite continuous treatment with high-dose inhaled glucocorticoids with or without oral glucocorticoids.
Methods:
In this randomized, double-blind clinical trial we assigned 576 patients with recurrent asthma exacerbations and evidence of eosinophilic inflammation despite high doses of inhaled glucocorticoids to one of three study groups. Patients were assigned to receive mepolizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody against interleukin-5, which was administered as either a 75-mg intravenous dose or a 100-mg subcutaneous dose or placebo every 4 weeks for 32 weeks. The primary outcome was the rate of exacerbations. Other outcomes included the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and scores on the St. George’s Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and the 5-item Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ-5).
Results:
The rate of exacerbations was reduced by 47% (95% confidence interval [CI], 29 to 61) among patients receiving intravenous mepolizumab and by 53% (95% CI, 37 to 65) among those receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab, as compared with those receiving placebo (p<0.001 for both comparisons). Exacerbations necessitating an emergency department visit or hospitalization were reduced by 32% in the group receiving intravenous mepolizumab and by 61% in the group receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab. At week 32, the mean increase from baseline in FEV1 was 100 ml greater in patients receiving intravenous mepolizumab than in those receiving placebo (p=0.02) and 98 ml greater in patients receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab than in those receiving placebo (p=0.03). The improvement from baseline in the SGRQ score was 6.4 points and 7.0 points greater in the intravenous and subcutaneous mepolizumab groups, respectively than in the placebo group, and the improvement in the ACQ-5 score was 0.42 points and 0.44 points greater in the two mepolizumab groups, respectively than in the placebo group (p<0.001 for all comparisons).
Conclusions:
Mepolizumab administered either intravenously or subcutaneously significantly reduced asthma exacerbations and was associated with improvements in markers of asthma control.
Given the original research abstract above, which of the following would be true if the authors had inadvertently encountered a type 1 error?
A) A type 1 error means the study is not significantly powered to detect a true difference between study groups.
B) A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.
C) A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is false, yet is accepted in error.
D) A type 1 error is a beta (β) error and is usually 0.1 or 0.2.
E) A type 1 error is dependent on the confidence interval of a study.
answer:
Reformatted Question: Given the original research abstract above, which of the following would be true if the authors had inadvertently encountered a <fact1>type 1 error</fact1>?

A) A <fact1>type 1 error</fact1> means the study is not significantly powered to detect a true difference between study groups.
B) A <fact1>type 1 error</fact1> occurs when the <fact2>null hypothesis</fact2> is true but is rejected in error.
C) A <fact1>type 1 error</fact1> occurs when the <fact2>null hypothesis</fact2> is false, yet is accepted in error.
D) A <fact1>type 1 error</fact1> is a <fact3>beta (β) error</fact3> and is usually 0.1 or 0.2.
E) A <fact1>type 1 error</fact1> is dependent on the <fact4>confidence interval</fact4> of a study.

Answer: B) A <fact1>type 1 error</fact1> occurs when the <fact2>null hypothesis</fact2> is true but is rejected in error.

Explanation: In the context of the research abstract, which discusses the efficacy of mepolizumab in reducing asthma exacerbations, a type 1 error would occur if the null hypothesis that mepolizumab has no effect on asthma exacerbations were true, but the study results led to the rejection of this hypothesis in error. This would mean that the observed reductions in exacerbations and improvements in markers of asthma control were due to chance rather than a real effect of the treatment.

question:
Background: There is a lack of consensus about whether the initial imaging method for patients with suspected nephrolithiasis should be computed tomography (CT) or ultrasonography.
Methods: In this multicenter, pragmatic, comparative effectiveness trial, we randomly assigned patients 18 to 76 years of age who presented to the emergency department with suspected nephrolithiasis to undergo initial diagnostic ultrasonography performed by an emergency physician (point-of-care ultrasonography), ultrasonography performed by a radiologist (radiology ultrasonography), or abdominal non-contrast CT. Subsequent management, including additional imaging, was at the discretion of the physician. We compared the three groups with respect to the 30-day incidence of high-risk diagnoses with complications that could be related to missed or delayed diagnosis and the 6-month cumulative radiation exposure. Secondary outcomes were serious adverse events, related serious adverse events (deemed attributable to study participation), pain (assessed on an 11-point visual-analog scale, with higher scores indicating more severe pain), return emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and diagnostic accuracy.
Results: A total of 2759 patients underwent randomization: 908 to point-of-care ultrasonography, 893 to radiology ultrasonography, and 958 to non-contrast CT abdomen The incidence of high-risk diagnoses with complications in the first 30 days was low (0.4%) and did not vary according to imaging method. The mean 6-month cumulative radiation exposure was significantly lower in the ultrasonography groups than in the CT group (p < 0.001). Serious adverse events occurred in 12.4% of the patients assigned to point-of-care ultrasonography, 10.8% of those assigned to radiology ultrasonography, and 11.2% of those assigned to CT (p = 0.50). Related adverse events were infrequent (incidence, 0.4%) and similar across groups. By 7 days, the average pain score was 2.0 in each group (p = 0.84). Return emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and diagnostic accuracy did not differ significantly among the groups.
Conclusions: Initial ultrasonography was associated with lower cumulative radiation exposure than initial CT, without significant differences in high-risk diagnoses with complications, serious adverse events, pain scores, return emergency department visits, or hospitalizations.
If the conclusion stated above was, in fact, due to the earlier detection of nephrolithiasis in patients undergoing point of care ultrasound, what type of bias would this exemplify?
A) Measurement bias
B) Recall bias
C) Lead-time bias
D) Selection bias
E) Length-time bias
answer:
Reformatted Question: If the conclusion stated above was, in fact, due to the earlier detection of <fact1>nephrolithiasis</fact1> in patients undergoing <fact2>point of care ultrasound</fact2>, what type of bias would this exemplify?

Answer: This scenario exemplifies {C} lead-time bias. Lead-time bias occurs when a screening test appears to prolong survival or improve outcomes simply because it detects the disease earlier in its course, rather than actually altering the disease's natural history. In this case, if the conclusion that <fact2>point of care ultrasound</fact2> is associated with better outcomes is due to the <fact3>earlier detection of nephrolithiasis</fact3>, it would mean that the apparent benefit is solely due to the earlier detection, rather than any actual change in the disease's progression or treatment efficacy.

question:
A 67-year-old man is brought to the hospital by his relatives. He complains of early satiety, abdominal discomfort after food intake, and abdominal bloating. These symptoms have been present since the patient was 52, but they were milder at that time so he paid little attention to them since. Tingling and decreased sensation in both lower extremities began a few months ago. His relatives also note that he has become excessively somnolent and forgetful. The patient’s medical history is significant for acute hepatitis B 20 years ago. He smokes a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks alcohol occasionally. His weight is 61 kg (134.5 lb), height is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in), and BMI is 18.6 kg/m2. His vital signs include: blood pressure 110/80 mm Hg, heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.1°C (96.9°F). The patient’s skin is pale, thin, dry, and hypoelastic. Lymph nodes and the thyroid gland are not enlarged. Lung and heart examinations are within normal limits for his age. The patient’s tongue is bright red with atrophic papillae. The abdomen is distended and tender to palpation in the epigastric area. Neurological examination shows symmetrical bilateral distal hypoesthesia for all sensations and decreased muscle strength in both upper and lower extremities. On a mini-mental status examination, the patient scores 25. The patient’s blood test results are as follows:
Erythrocytes 2.8 x 109/mm3
Hb 8.6 g/dL
Ht 37%
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin  49.9 pg/cell (3.1 fmol/cell)
Mean corpuscular volume 142 µm3 (142 fL)
Reticulocyte count 0.3%
Total leukocyte count 3,070/mm3
Neutrophils 54%
Lymphocyte 32%
Eosinophil 3%
Monocyte 11%
Basophil 0%
Platelet count 195,000/mm3
HbA1C 4.3%
Fasting plasma glucose 4.6 mmol/l (82.9 mg/dL)
Aspartate aminotransferase 22 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 19 U/L
Amylase 32 U/L
Total bilirubin 32 µmol/L (1.87 mg/dL)
Conjugated bilirubin 8 µmol/L (0.4677 mg/L)
Which of the following options best explains the patient’s neurological and psychiatric symptoms?
A) Chronic bilirubin toxicity
B) Chronic hyperglycemia
C) Chronic acetaldehyde influence
D) Impaired methylation of myelin phospholipids
E) Influence of pseudo-neurotransmitters

Which of the following options best explains the patient’s <fact3>neurological and psychiatric symptoms</fact3>?

Answer: Analyzing the patient's presentation, the <fact1>67-year-old man</fact1> has been experiencing <fact2>early satiety, abdominal discomfort after food intake, and abdominal bloating</fact2> for a prolonged period. He also exhibits <fact3>tingling and decreased sensation in both lower extremities</fact3> and has become <fact4>excessively somnolent and forgetful</fact4>. His medical history is significant for <fact5>acute hepatitis B 20 years ago</fact5>, and he has a history of <fact6>smoking and occasional alcohol consumption</fact6>. The patient's neurological examination shows <fact7>symmetrical bilateral distal hypoesthesia for all sensations and decreased muscle strength in both upper and lower extremities</fact7>. Given these symptoms, the patient's condition is likely related to a nutritional deficiency. The patient's blood test results show a low <fact8>mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 142 µm3 (142 fL)</fact8> and a low <fact9>reticulocyte count of 0.3%</fact9>, indicating a possible deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate, which are essential for the production of myelin. The patient's neurological and psychiatric symptoms can be explained by impaired methylation of myelin phospholipids due to a deficiency in vitamin B12. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents with episodes of palpitations for the past 3 weeks. He says that he has episodes where he feels his heart is ‘racing and pounding’, lasting 1–2 hours on average. Initially, he says the episodes would happen 1–2 times per week but now happen almost every day. This last episode has been constant for the past 2 days. He denies any seizure, loss of consciousness, dizziness, chest pain, or similar symptoms in the past. His past medical history is significant for an ischemic stroke of the right anterior cerebral artery 1 month ago, status post intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) with still some residual neurologic impairment, and long-standing gastroesophageal reflux secondary to a hiatal hernia, managed medically. The patient reports a 15-pack-year smoking history, but no alcohol or recreational drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg, pulse 105/min, and respiratory rate 16/min. On physical examination, muscle strength in the lower extremities is 4/5 on the left and 5/5 on the right, along with sensory loss on the left, all of which is improved from his previous exam 3 weeks ago. There is a loss of the left half of the visual field bilaterally which is stable from the previous exam. Cardiac examination is significant for a new-onset irregular rate and rhythm. No rubs, thrills or murmurs. A noncontrast computed tomography (CT) scan shows evidence of an area of infarction in the vicinity of the right anterior cerebral artery showing normal interval change with no evidence of new hemorrhage or expansion of the area of infarction. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, which is shown in the exhibit (see image below). Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to best prevent future cerebrovascular accidents (CVAs) in this patient?
A) Begin aspirin therapy
B) Begin clopidogrel
C) Carotid endarterectomy
D) Begin warfarin and heparin
E) Begin warfarin
answer:
Reformatted Question:

He says that he has episodes where he feels his heart is ‘racing and pounding’, lasting 1–2 hours on average. Initially, he says the episodes would happen 1–2 times per week but now happen almost every day. This last episode has been constant for the past 2 days. He denies any <fact3>seizure, loss of consciousness, dizziness, chest pain, or similar symptoms</fact3> in the past. His past medical history is significant for a <fact4>ischemic stroke of the right anterior cerebral artery 1 month ago</fact4>, status post intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) with still some residual neurologic impairment, and long-standing gastroesophageal reflux secondary to a hiatal hernia, managed medically. The patient reports a <fact5>15-pack-year smoking history</fact5>, but no alcohol or recreational drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg, pulse 105/min, and respiratory rate 16/min. On physical examination, muscle strength in the lower extremities is 4/5 on the left and 5/5 on the right, along with sensory loss on the left, all of which is improved from his previous exam 3 weeks ago. There is a loss of the left half of the visual field bilaterally which is stable from the previous exam. Cardiac examination is significant for a new-onset <fact6>irregular rate and rhythm</fact6>. No rubs, thrills or murmurs. A noncontrast computed tomography (CT) scan shows evidence of an area of infarction in the vicinity of the right anterior cerebral artery showing normal interval change with no evidence of new hemorrhage or expansion of the area of infarction. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, which is shown in the exhibit (see image below). Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to best prevent future cerebrovascular accidents (CVAs) in this patient?

Answer: Given the patient's history of <fact4>ischemic stroke of the right anterior cerebral artery 1 month ago</fact4> and current presentation with <fact2>palpitations</fact2> and a new-onset <fact6>irregular rate and rhythm</fact6>, the most appropriate intervention to prevent future cerebrovascular accidents (CVAs) would be to address the cardiac arrhythmia. Considering the patient's history of ischemic stroke and the presence of an irregular rate and rhythm, anticoagulation would be the most effective way to prevent future CVAs. Among the options provided, beginning warfarin (option E) is the most appropriate choice, as it is an anticoagulant that can help prevent the formation of blood clots that could lead to another ischemic stroke.

question:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department for progressively worsening fatigue, malaise, fever, and abdominal pain. He reports that his symptoms began approximately 1 week ago and he has noticed episodes of diarrhea. He recently started melatonin and magnesium supplementation in hopes of improving his sleep. Medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder that required multiple hospital admissions for management of acute pancreatitis and cirrhosis. He states that he occasionally injects heroin intravenously. Temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 17/min. Physical examination is significant for scleral icterus, hepatomegaly, ascites, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory testing is significant for leukocytosis and metabolic acidosis. A paracentesis is performed and he is admitted into the hospital to receive intravenous cefotaxime and albumin. Ascitic fluid analysis demonstrates a polymorphonuclear cell count of 280 cells/mm^3, serum-ascites albumin gradient of 1.3 g/dL, and a culture positive for Escherichia coli sensitive to cefotaxime and ceftriaxone. On hospital day 2, the nurse reports that the patient is oliguric in the setting of constant fluid intake. Physical examination is unchanged. Laboratory testing is significant for a serum sodium of 131 mEq/L and creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL (it was 0.9 mg/dL on admission). Urine studies are significant for a low urine sodium level, without evidence of blood or protein. Since the hospital admission, he has not been started on any new medications. Which of the following will be the best treatment option for this patient?
A) Adding dopamine to his treatment regimen
B) Adding lisinopril to his treatment regimen
C) Liver transplantation
D) Switching cefotaxime to ceftriaxone
E) Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department for <fact2>progressively worsening fatigue, malaise, fever, and abdominal pain</fact2>. He reports that his symptoms began approximately <fact3>1 week ago</fact3> and he has noticed episodes of <fact4>diarrhea</fact4>. He recently started <fact5>melatonin and magnesium supplementation</fact5> in hopes of improving his sleep. Medical history is significant for <fact6>alcohol use disorder</fact6> that required multiple hospital admissions for management of <fact7>acute pancreatitis and cirrhosis</fact7>. He states that he occasionally injects <fact8>heroin intravenously</fact8>. Temperature is <fact9>100°F (37.8°C)</fact9>, blood pressure is <fact10>105/70 mmHg</fact10>, pulse is <fact11>92/min</fact11>, and respirations are <fact12>17/min</fact12>. Physical examination is significant for <fact13>scleral icterus, hepatomegaly, ascites, and diffuse abdominal tenderness</fact13>. Laboratory testing is significant for <fact14>leukocytosis and metabolic acidosis</fact14>. A <fact15>paracentesis is performed</fact15> and he is admitted into the hospital to receive <fact16>intravenous cefotaxime and albumin</fact16>. Ascitic fluid analysis demonstrates a <fact17>polymorphonuclear cell count of 280 cells/mm^3</fact17>, <fact18>serum-ascites albumin gradient of 1.3 g/dL</fact18>, and a culture positive for <fact19>Escherichia coli sensitive to cefotaxime and ceftriaxone</fact19>. On hospital day 2, the nurse reports that the patient is <fact20>oliguric in the setting of constant fluid intake</fact20>. Physical examination is unchanged. Laboratory testing is significant for a <fact21>serum sodium of 131 mEq/L</fact21> and <fact22>creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL (it was 0.9 mg/dL on admission)</fact22>. Urine studies are significant for a <fact23>low urine sodium level</fact23>, without evidence of blood or protein. Since the hospital admission, he has not been started on any new medications. Which of the following will be the best treatment option for this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact20>oliguria</fact20> despite constant fluid intake and the development of <fact22>increased creatinine levels</fact22> from 0.9 mg/dL on admission to 1.8 mg/dL, along with a <fact23>low urine sodium level</fact23>, it suggests the development of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), a type of kidney dysfunction that occurs in individuals with advanced liver disease, such as cirrhosis (<fact7>acute pancreatitis and cirrhosis</fact7>). The best treatment option for HRS is the use of vasoconstrictors such as dopamine, but given the options, the most suitable treatment for this patient, who is already receiving <fact16>intravenous cefotaxime and albumin</fact16>, would be to add a medication that can help manage the oliguria and prevent further kidney damage. However, none of the provided options directly address HRS. Among the given options, adding dopamine (Option A) could potentially help manage the oliguria by improving renal perfusion, although it is not the first-line treatment for HRS. The other options are not directly relevant to the management of oliguria or HRS in this context. Therefore, the best answer is {A}.

question:
A 4-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. He presents to the pediatric ward with fever, dyspnea, and cough, which he developed 3 days ago. His mother also reports he had poor weight gain despite a good appetite during the past 2 months as well as frequent stools with an unpleasant smell. He was born at 29 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is meeting all of his milestones and is up to date with all vaccines. The child is breastfed exclusively. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, the heart rate is 109/min, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). The patient’s weight is between the 5th and 10th percentile. His length is between the 50th and 75th percentile. The patient is sluggish and reacts torpidly to examination. His skin is pale and dry with decreased turgor and elasticity. On auscultation, there are diminished vesicular sounds and disseminated moist rales at the bases of both lungs. Heart sounds are normal. The abdomen is distended without palpable masses. The patient’s blood analysis shows the following findings:
Complete blood count 
 Erythrocytes  3.3 x 106/mm3
 Hb  12 g/dL
 Total leukocyte count  17,500/mm3
 Neutrophils
 59%
 Lymphocytes
 32%
 Eosinophils
 3%
 Monocytes
 6%
 Basophils
 0
Platelet count
232,000/mm3
Sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. A sweat test shows chloride concentration of 85 mEq/L (elevated). Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s symptoms?
A) Neutrophil elastase damages lung tissue due to lack of alpha-1-antitrypsin.
B) Abnormal CFTR protein
C) Eosinophils infiltrate blood vessel walls.
D) Electron transport chain in mitochondria is disrupted due to lack of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
E) Due to mutations in dynein, the ciliary epithelium fails to provide appropriate mucociliary clearance.
answer:

<fact28>Sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa</fact28>. A <fact29>sweat test shows chloride concentration of 85 mEq/L (elevated)</fact29>. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: The patient presents with symptoms such as <fact2>fever, dyspnea, and cough</fact2>, <fact4>poor weight gain despite a good appetite</fact4>, and <fact5>requent stools with an unpleasant smell</fact5>, which are suggestive of a gastrointestinal and respiratory issue. Additionally, the patient has an elevated chloride concentration in the sweat test (<fact29>85 mEq/L</fact29>), which is a diagnostic criterion for cystic fibrosis (CF). The presence of <fact28>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</fact28> in the sputum culture further supports this diagnosis, as Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common pathogen in CF patients. The pathogenesis of CF is related to the abnormal CFTR protein, which is a chloride channel that regulates the components of sweat, digestive fluids, and mucus. Therefore, the correct answer is {B} Abnormal CFTR protein.

question:
A 68-year-old woman presents with an intermittent throbbing headache with an onset approximately 3 weeks ago. The pain is bilateral, “band-like,” and extends to the neck. The patient rates the 4 points out of 10 on a visual scale. The headache is not accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, and is not aggravated by movements, but gets worse when the patient coughs or laughs. The headache has persisted throughout the day and is usually worse in the morning an hour after she has breakfast and taken her medications. The patient was diagnosed with stage 1 arterial hypertension 2 years ago and stable angina pectoris 3 weeks ago. Currently, she takes aspirin (81 mg once daily), rosuvastatin (10 mg once daily), lisinopril (20 mg once daily), and isosorbide mononitrate (60 mg once daily). She has been menopausal for the last 15 years. In addition to her chief complaint, she also notes that she had a runny nose with a temperature elevation approximately 3 weeks ago, and her headache was linked to that acute illness. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 135/80 mm Hg, heart rate 76/min, respiratory rate 14/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). The physical examination reveals S2 accentuation that is best heard in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border. Palpation of the paranasal sinuses is painless. The neurologic exam shows no focal symptoms, no pain on palpation of the trigeminal points, and no meningeal symptoms. What is the most likely mechanism underlying the patient’s headaches?
A) Meningeal irritation by blood products originating from a chronic subdural hematoma
B) Dissection of an intracerebral vessel
C) Pressure created by the content of the paranasal sinuses
D) Meningeal irritation by a growing intracranial neoplasm
E) Dilation of the intracerebral arterioles
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old woman</fact1> presents with an <fact2>intermittent throbbing headache</fact2> with an onset approximately <fact3>3 weeks ago</fact3>. The pain is <fact4>bilateral, “band-like,” and extends to the neck</fact4>. The patient rates the <fact5>4 points out of 10 on a visual scale</fact5>. The headache is not accompanied by <fact6>nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia</fact6>, and is not aggravated by <fact7>movements</fact7>, but gets worse when the patient <fact8>coughs or laughs</fact8>. The headache has persisted throughout the day and is usually worse in the morning an hour after she has <fact9>breakfast and taken her medications</fact9>. The patient was diagnosed with <fact10>stage 1 arterial hypertension 2 years ago</fact10> and <fact11>stable angina pectoris 3 weeks ago</fact11>. Currently, she takes <fact12>aspirin (81 mg once daily), rosuvastatin (10 mg once daily), lisinopril (20 mg once daily), and isosorbide mononitrate (60 mg once daily)</fact12>. She has been <fact13>menopausal for the last 15 years</fact13>. In addition to her chief complaint, she also notes that she had a <fact14>runny nose with a temperature elevation approximately 3 weeks ago</fact14>, and her headache was linked to that <fact15>acute illness</fact15>. The vital signs are as follows: <fact16>blood pressure 135/80 mm Hg, heart rate 76/min, respiratory rate 14/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉)</fact16>. The physical examination reveals <fact17>S2 accentuation that is best heard in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border</fact17>. Palpation of the <fact18>paranasal sinuses is painless</fact18>. The neurologic exam shows <fact19>no focal symptoms, no pain on palpation of the trigeminal points, and no meningeal symptoms</fact19>. What is the most likely mechanism underlying the patient’s headaches?

Answer: 
The patient's headache, described as <fact4>bilateral, “band-like,” and extending to the neck</fact4> with an onset approximately <fact3>3 weeks ago</fact3>, and linked to a <fact15>recent acute illness</fact15> characterized by a <fact14>runny nose with a temperature elevation</fact14>, suggests a tension-type headache. The fact that the headache is not accompanied by <fact6>nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia</fact6> and is not aggravated by <fact7>movements</fact7> further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the headache's characteristic worsening when the patient <fact8>coughs or laughs</fact8> and its persistence throughout the day, especially in the morning after <fact9>breakfast and taking medications</fact9>, are consistent with a tension-type headache. The patient's medical history, including <fact10>stage 1 arterial hypertension</fact10> and <fact11>stable angina pectoris</fact11>, and her current medications, including <fact12>aspirin, rosuvastatin, lisinopril, and isosorbide mononitrate</fact12>, do not directly suggest an alternative headache mechanism. Furthermore, the physical examination findings, such as <fact17>S2 accentuation</fact17> and <fact18>painless paranasal sinuses</fact18>, along with the absence of <fact19>focal symptoms, pain on palpation of the trigeminal points, and meningeal symptoms</fact19>, do not indicate a more serious underlying condition. Therefore, the most likely mechanism underlying the patient's headaches is <fact20>dilation of the intracerebral arterioles</fact20>, which is a characteristic feature of tension-type headaches.

question:
A 69-year-old male with a longstanding history of hypertension and high cholesterol presents with abdominal pain and ‘bruising on his feet’. The patient states that his symptoms started about a week ago and have steadily worsened. He describes the abdominal pain as mild to moderate, dull, and deeply localized to the umbilical region. Past medical history is significant for 2 transient ischemic attacks 6 months prior, characterized by a sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking but recovered fully within 30 minutes. Current medications are sildenafil 100 mg orally as needed. Patient reports a 30-pack-year smoking history and heavy alcohol use on the weekends. Review of systems is significant for decreased appetite and feeling easily full. Vitals are temperature 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 155/89 mm Hg, pulse 89/min, respirations 16/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The cardiac exam is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Carotid bruit present on the right. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds present. A pulsatile abdominal mass is felt in the lower umbilical region. Patient’s feet have the following appearance seen in the picture. Abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Contrast CT reveals a small, unruptured AAA (diameter 4.1 cm). High flow supplemental oxygen and fluid resuscitation are initiated. Morphine sulfate and metoprolol are administered. Which of the following is the best course of treatment for this patient?
 
A) Discharge with clinical surveillance and annual ultrasound
B) Discharge with clinical surveillance and ultrasound every 6 months
C) Elective endovascular repair
D) Elective open surgical repair
E) Emergency open surgical repair
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>69-year-old male</fact1> with a longstanding history of <fact2>hypertension and high cholesterol</fact2> presents with <fact3>abdominal pain</fact3> and <fact4>‘bruising on his feet’</fact4>. The patient states that his symptoms started about a week ago and have steadily worsened. He describes the <fact3>abdominal pain</fact3> as mild to moderate, dull, and deeply localized to the <fact5>umbilical region</fact5>. Past medical history is significant for <fact6>2 transient ischemic attacks 6 months prior</fact6>, characterized by a sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking but recovered fully within 30 minutes. Current medications are <fact7>sildenafil 100 mg orally as needed</fact7>. Patient reports a <fact8>30-pack-year smoking history</fact8> and <fact9>heavy alcohol use on the weekends</fact9>. Review of systems is significant for <fact10>decreased appetite</fact10> and feeling easily full. Vitals are <fact11>temperature 37°C (98.6°F)</fact11>, <fact12>blood pressure 155/89 mm Hg</fact12>, <fact13>pulse 89/min</fact13>, <fact14>respirations 16/min</fact14>, and <fact15>oxygen saturation 98% on room air</fact15>. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The cardiac exam is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. <fact16>Carotid bruit present on the right</fact16>. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds present. A <fact17>pulsatile abdominal mass</fact17> is felt in the <fact5>lower umbilical region</fact5>. Patient’s feet have the following appearance seen in the picture. <fact18>Abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)</fact18>. <fact19>Contrast CT reveals a small, unruptured AAA (diameter 4.1 cm)</fact19>. High flow supplemental oxygen and fluid resuscitation are initiated. Morphine sulfate and metoprolol are administered. Which of the following is the best course of treatment for this patient?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation, including a <fact17>pulsatile abdominal mass</fact17> in the <fact5>lower umbilical region</fact5> and the findings of <fact18>abdominal ultrasound</fact18> and <fact19>contrast CT</fact19> revealing a <fact20>small, unruptured AAA (diameter 4.1 cm)</fact20>, the best course of treatment would be to monitor the aneurysm with regular follow-up and imaging to assess for any changes in size or symptoms. The American Heart Association recommends that small AAAs (less than 4 cm in diameter) be monitored with ultrasound every 6-12 months. Considering the patient's <fact20>small, unruptured AAA (diameter 4.1 cm)</fact20> and the absence of any signs of rupture or severe symptoms, the best answer is {B} Discharge with clinical surveillance and ultrasound every 6 months.

question:
A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-week history of fatigue and headache that have gotten progressively worse. He has allergic asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He immigrated to the USA from Thailand 9 years ago. He lives by himself and works as a waiter in a restaurant. He has had 6 lifetime male sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He drinks 1–2 beers daily. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Examination of the mouth shows several white patches on the tongue and oral mucosa that can be easily scraped off with a tongue blade. On mental status examination, the patient is somnolent and has short-term memory deficits. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.6 g/dL
Leukocyte count 9,600/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 80%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 17%
Monocytes 2%
CD4+ T-lymphocytes 80/mm3 (Normal ≥ 500)
Platelet count 328,000/mm3
Serum
pH 7.36
Na+ 135 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 4.8 mEq/L
HCO3- 22 mEq/L
Glucose 95 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
BUN 16 mg/dL
Bilirubin, total 0.7 mg/dL
AST 13 U/L
ALT 15 U/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 10 mm/hour
HIV test positive
A lumbar puncture is performed and an opening pressure of 150 mm H2O is noted. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 25/mm3 (60% lymphocytes), protein concentration of 52 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 37 mg/dL. India ink stain shows organisms with prominent capsules. Blood cultures are drawn. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's neurological symptoms?"
A) Pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and folinic acid
B) Amphotericin B and flucytosine
C) Fluconazole
D) Vancomycin and meropenem
E) Valacyclovir
answer:

Blood cultures are drawn. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's neurological symptoms?

Answer: 
Analyzing the patient's presentation, the <fact1>46-year-old man</fact1> with a <fact2>4-week history of fatigue and headache</fact2> and <fact10>somnolent and short-term memory deficits</fact10> is indicative of central nervous system (CNS) involvement. The patient's <fact9>white patches on the tongue and oral mucosa</fact9> are consistent with oral thrush, a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals. The patient's <fact32>HIV test is positive</fact32> and has a significantly low <fact17>CD4+ T-lymphocytes count of 80/mm3</fact17>, indicating advanced HIV disease. The <fact33>lumbar puncture</fact33> results, including <fact34>leukocyte count of 25/mm3</fact34>, <fact35>protein concentration of 52 mg/dL</fact35>, and <fact36>glucose concentration of 37 mg/dL</fact36>, along with the <fact37>India ink stain showing organisms with prominent capsules</fact37>, are consistent with cryptococcal meningitis, a common opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients. Therefore, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's neurological symptoms is {B} Amphotericin B and flucytosine.

question:
A 61-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive thirst, frequent urination, and partial visual loss in both eyes for 1 day. His family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in his mother and cousin. His weight is 112 kg ( 246.9 lb), height 187 cm (6 ft 1 in), blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate: 89/min, respiratory rate: 14/min, and temperature: 36.7℃ (98.4℉). The physical examination is significant for dry skin, a pustular rash over the patient’s shoulders and back, an accentuated second heart sound (S2) best heard in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border, and distal loss of vibration sensitivity in both feet. A fundoscopic examination shows small red dots in the superficial retinal layers suggestive of microaneurysms. The HbA1c is 9% and the urinalysis shows the following:
Color Pale yellow (light/pale-to-dark/deep amber)
Clarity Cloudy
pH 6.6
Specific gravity 1.010
Glucose 199 mg/dl
Ketones None
Nitrites Negative
Leukocyte esterase Negative
Bilirubin Negative
Urinary bilirubin Traces
Red blood cells 3 RBCs
Protein 120 mg/d
RBCs ≤ 2 RBCs/hpf
WBCs 22 WBCs/hpf
Epithelial cells 27 squamous epithelial cells/hpf
Casts 5 hyaline casts/lpf
Crystals Occasional
Bacteria None
Yeast Present
Which of the following statements best describes the cause of this patient’s glucosuria?
A) Yeasts metabolize glucogenic amino acids which are filtered in the urine into glucose
B) There is a disruption of primary active transport of glucose in the proximal renal tubules
C) Secondary active transporters fail to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules
D) There is a disruption of passive transport of the glucose in the proximal renal tubules
E) Glucosuria results from increased glomerular filtration rate
answer:

His family history is significant for <fact1>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact1> in his mother and cousin. His weight is 112 kg ( 246.9 lb), height 187 cm (6 ft 1 in), blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate: 89/min, respiratory rate: 14/min, and temperature: 36.7℃ (98.4℉). Bilirubin Negative
Urinary bilirubin Traces
Red blood cells 3 RBCs
Protein 120 mg/d
RBCs ≤ 2 RBCs/hpf
WBCs 22 WBCs/hpf
Epithelial cells 27 squamous epithelial cells/hpf
Casts 5 hyaline casts/lpf
Crystals Occasional
Bacteria None
Yeast Present
Which of the following statements best describes the cause of this patient’s glucosuria?

Answer: The patient's glucosuria, as indicated by the presence of <fact4>glucose 199 mg/dl</fact4> in the urinalysis, is most likely due to an inability of the kidneys to reabsorb glucose. Given the patient's high <fact3>HbA1c of 9%</fact3> and the presence of <fact2>microaneurysms</fact2> in the fundoscopic examination, which are indicative of diabetic retinopathy, it is clear that the patient has uncontrolled <fact1>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact1>. In diabetes, the high blood glucose levels exceed the reabsorption capacity of the renal tubules, leading to glucosuria. The correct answer is C) Secondary active transporters fail to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules.

question:
A 24-year-old man, who recently migrated from a developing country, presents to a physician because of a 2-year history of cough, blood in his sputum, fever, and weight loss. His sputum smear and culture confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. His Mantoux test is 2 mm × 3 mm, and his chest radiograph is normal. High-sensitivity enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for HIV-1 and Western blot assay for HIV-1 are positive. His CD4+ T cell count is 90/μL and HIV RNA is 30,000 copies/mL. He is started on a 4-drug regimen consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol in appropriate doses. He becomes sputum smear-negative after 4 weeks and reports significant improvement in symptoms. After another 4 weeks, the physician removes pyrazinamide from the antitubercular regimen and adds antiretroviral therapy (dolutegravir/tenofovir/emtricitabine). After 3 weeks, the patient presents with complaints of fever and significantly increased cough for 3 days. There is no respiratory distress but generalized lymphadenopathy is present. His chest radiograph shows pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, sputum smear is negative, Mantoux test is 12 mm × 14 mm, CD4+ T cell count is 370/μL, and HIV RNA is 2,900 copies/mL. What is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?
A) Stop antiretroviral therapy and continue antitubercular therapy
B) Change antiretroviral therapy to darunavir/ritonavir plus tenofovir/emtricitabine
C) Change antitubercular therapy to isoniazid-rifampin-pyrazinamide-ethambutol-streptomycin
D) Change antitubercular therapy to isoniazid-rifampin-ethambutol-streptomycin
E) Continue antitubercular therapy and antiretroviral therapy without any change
answer:

His <fact3>sputum smear and culture confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis</fact3>. His <fact4>Mantoux test is 2 mm × 3 mm</fact4>, and his <fact5>chest radiograph is normal</fact5>. High-sensitivity enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for HIV-1 and Western blot assay for HIV-1 are positive. His <fact6>CD4+ T cell count is 90/μL</fact6> and <fact7>HIV RNA is 30,000 copies/mL</fact7>. He is started on a <fact8>4-drug regimen consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol</fact8> in appropriate doses. He becomes <fact9>sputum smear-negative after 4 weeks</fact9> and reports significant improvement in symptoms. After another 4 weeks, the physician removes <fact10>pyrazinamide from the antitubercular regimen</fact10> and adds <fact11>antiretroviral therapy (dolutegravir/tenofovir/emtricitabine)</fact11>. After 3 weeks, the patient presents with complaints of <fact12>fever and significantly increased cough for 3 days</fact12>. There is no respiratory distress but <fact13>generalized lymphadenopathy is present</fact13>. His <fact14>chest radiograph shows pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal lymphadenopathy</fact14>, <fact15>sputum smear is negative</fact15>, <fact16>Mantoux test is 12 mm × 14 mm</fact16>, <fact17>CD4+ T cell count is 370/μL</fact17>, and <fact18>HIV RNA is 2,900 copies/mL</fact18>. What is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?

Answer: Considering the patient's recent initiation of <fact11>antiretroviral therapy (dolutegravir/tenofovir/emtricitabine)</fact11> and the subsequent development of <fact12>fever and significantly increased cough for 3 days</fact12> along with <fact13>generalized lymphadenopathy</fact13> and <fact14>pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal lymphadenopathy on chest radiograph</fact14>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of an immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). This condition occurs when the immune system begins to recover due to antiretroviral therapy, leading to an exaggerated response to a previously acquired opportunistic infection, in this case, tuberculosis. Given the patient's <fact17>significantly increased CD4+ T cell count to 370/μL</fact17> and <fact18>decreased HIV RNA to 2,900 copies/mL</fact18>, it is clear that the antiretroviral therapy is effective. Therefore, the most appropriate initial step in treatment is to <fact19>continue antitubercular therapy and antiretroviral therapy without any change</fact19>, as discontinuing antiretroviral therapy could lead to a decline in the patient's immune status and worsening of HIV disease. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 16-year-old female presents to her primary care physician due to lack of menstruation. She has never had a period and is anxious that she is not “keeping up” with her friends. She states that her breasts began developing when she was 13, and she had a growth spurt around the same time. Review of systems reveals that she has also been getting headaches every few months over the last year with some photosensitivity and nausea each time. Ibuprofen relieves her symptoms. The patient is a competitive ice skater and has never been sexually active. Her mother has a history of migraine headaches, and her older sister has a history of bipolar disorder. Both underwent menarche at age 15. At this visit, the patient’s temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg, and respirations are 13/min. Her body mass index is 23.8 kg/m^2. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Both breasts are Tanner IV with no expressable discharge. Pelvic and axillary hair growth is also Tanner IV. The patient is unable to tolerate a full pelvic exam, but the part of the vaginal canal that is examined is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are ordered and are below:

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
K+: 4.1 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 12 mg/dL
Glucose: 73 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Ca2+: 9.7 mg/dL
Mg2+: 1.7 mEq/L
AST: 11 U/L
ALT: 11 U/L
Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH): 16.2 mIU/mL (4.7-21.5 mIU/ml)
Estrogen: 240 pg/mL (64-357 pg/mL)

Abdominal ultrasound is performed and shows a normal uterus and ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Hypothalamic amenorrhea
B) Hyperprolactinemia
C) Imperforate hymen
D) Vaginal septum
E) Normal development

The patient's presentation of <fact2>lack of menstruation</fact2> with <fact3>breast development</fact3> and <fact4>growth spurt</fact4> at age 13, along with normal laboratory values (<fact27>FSH</fact27> and <fact28>estrogen</fact28> within normal ranges) and a <fact29>normal uterus and ovaries</fact29> on ultrasound, suggests that she is experiencing a normal delay in menarche. Additionally, the patient's <fact13>body mass index is 23.8 kg/m^2</fact13>, which is within the normal range, and she has no other signs of hormonal imbalances or anatomical abnormalities. question:
A 23-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with fever, chest discomfort, tachypnea, pain, needle-like sensations in the upper extremities, and profuse sweating. He also complains of a gradual decrease in vision over the past 3 months. He is a bodybuilding competitor and has a competition coming up in 1 week. The man reports that his symptoms appeared suddenly, 30 minutes after he took 2 foreign-manufactured fat-burning pills instead of the 1 he usually takes. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, heart rate is 137/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F). Physical examination reveals a reddish maculopapular rash over the patient’s trunk, diminished lung and heart sounds, tenderness to palpation in his abdomen, and rotational bilateral nystagmus with an alternating gaze-dependent fast component. Ophthalmologic examination shows bilateral cataracts. The patient’s total blood count is as follows:
Erythrocytes 4.4 x 109/mm3
Hb 12 g/dL
Total leukocyte count  3750/mm3
Neutrophils 57%
Lymphocyte 37%
Eosinophil 1%
Monocyte 5%
Basophil 0%
Platelet count 209,000/mm3
Which of the following statements best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
A) The patient’s symptoms are caused by an increased concentration of epinephrine released by the adrenal glands in response to the consumed substance.
B) The drug caused uncoupling of the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation.
C) The patient has a pyretic reaction due to bacterial contamination of the pills.
D) The patient’s condition is due to a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction triggered by the drug.
E) The drug has stimulated the hypothalamic temperature center to produce hyperthermia.
answer:

Physical examination reveals a <fact12>reddish maculopapular rash over the patient’s trunk</fact12>, <fact13>diminished lung and heart sounds</fact13>, <fact14>tenderness to palpation in his abdomen</fact14>, and <fact15>rotational bilateral nystagmus with an alternating gaze-dependent fast component</fact15>. Erythrocytes <fact17>4.4 x 10^9/mm3</fact17>
Hb <fact18>12 g/dL</fact18>
Total leukocyte count <fact19>3750/mm3</fact19>
Neutrophils <fact20>57%</fact20>
Lymphocyte <fact21>37%</fact21>
Eosinophil <fact22>1%</fact22>
Monocyte <fact23>5%</fact23>
Basophil <fact24>0%</fact24>
Platelet count <fact25>209,000/mm3</fact25>
Which of the following statements best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?

Answer: B) The drug caused uncoupling of the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation.

Explanation: The patient's symptoms, including <fact2>fever, chest discomfort, tachypnea, pain, needle-like sensations in the upper extremities, and profuse sweating</fact2>, along with the physical examination findings of a <fact12>reddish maculopapular rash</fact12>, <fact13>diminished lung and heart sounds</fact13>, <fact14>tenderness to palpation in his abdomen</fact14>, and <fact15>rotational bilateral nystagmus</fact15>, suggest a systemic and severe reaction to the consumed substance. The patient's total blood count shows a normal <fact17>erythrocyte count</fact17>, <fact18>hemoglobin level</fact18>, and <fact25>platelet count</fact25>, but a low <fact19>total leukocyte count</fact19> with a relatively normal differential. The most significant clue is the patient's report of taking <fact6>2 foreign-manufactured fat-burning pills</fact6> instead of the usual <fact7>1 pill</fact7>, which suggests an overdose or an adverse reaction to the substance. Considering the symptoms and the laboratory findings, the most plausible explanation is that the drug caused uncoupling of the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a severe systemic reaction. This is consistent with the patient's symptoms of hyperthermia (<fact11>temperature is 39.9°C or 103.8°F</fact11>), tachycardia (<fact9>heart rate is 137/min</fact9>), and tachypnea (<fact10>respiratory rate is 26/min</fact10>), as well as the presence of bilateral cataracts (<fact16>bilateral cataracts</fact16>).

question:
A 74-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to her primary care doctor by her son who is concerned about the patient's ability to manage her activities of daily living. She has been living alone since her husband passed away 2 years ago. She has remained an active member of her retirement community's wine club; however, she stopped attending the meetings 3 weeks ago. She is generally able to her maintain her house, but her house appears more disorganized over the past 2 weeks. She generally drives short distances but avoids driving long distances as she occasionally gets lost when navigating new areas. She feels like her balance is getting worse, but she has not fallen. She has noticed increased urinary urgency over the past 8 months and has had 2 episodes of incontinence. Despite these changes, she reports feeling well. She drinks 4-6 glasses of wine per day. She was started on multiple medications for worsening anxiety by her psychiatrist 1 month ago. Her BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 99.8°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 115/65 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 17/min. On examination, she is oriented to person and time but not place or situation. She does not seem to recognize her doctor despite knowing him for many years. She becomes somnolent intermittently throughout the interview. She can recall 0/3 words after 5 minutes. She has a low-frequency tremor in her right arm that increases in severity with deliberate movement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Alzheimer dementia
B) Delirium
C) Lewy body dementia
D) Normal pressure hydrocephalus
E) Pseudodementia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>74-year-old woman</fact1> with a history of <fact2>hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact2> is brought to her primary care doctor by her son who is concerned about the patient's ability to manage her <fact3>activities of daily living</fact3>. She has been living alone since her husband passed away <fact4>2 years ago</fact4>. She has remained an active member of her retirement community's wine club; however, she stopped attending the meetings <fact5>3 weeks ago</fact5>. She drinks <fact11>4-6 glasses of wine per day</fact11>. She was started on multiple medications for worsening anxiety by her psychiatrist <fact12>1 month ago</fact12>. Her BMI is <fact13>31 kg/m^2</fact13>. Her temperature is <fact14>99.8°F (37.7°C)</fact14>, blood pressure is <fact15>115/65 mmHg</fact15>, pulse is <fact16>95/min</fact16>, and respirations are <fact17>17/min</fact17>. On examination, she is oriented to <fact18>person and time but not place or situation</fact18>. She does not seem to recognize her doctor despite knowing him for many years. She becomes <fact19>somnolent intermittently throughout the interview</fact19>. She can recall <fact20>0/3 words after 5 minutes</fact20>. She has a <fact21>low-frequency tremor in her right arm that increases in severity with deliberate movement</fact21>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the most relevant information includes her <fact3>decline in managing activities of daily living</fact3>, <fact6>disorganization at home</fact6>, <fact7>getting lost in new areas</fact7>, <fact8>worsening balance</fact8>, <fact9>increased urinary urgency</fact9>, and <fact10>incontinence</fact10>. Additionally, her <fact11>alcohol consumption</fact11> and <fact12>recently started medications for anxiety</fact12> could be contributing factors. However, the key findings that point towards the diagnosis are her <fact18>disorientation to place and situation</fact18>, <fact19>somnolence</fact19>, <fact20>poor short-term memory</fact20>, and <fact21>low-frequency tremor</fact21>. These symptoms are more indicative of a delirium state, which is characterized by an acute and fluctuating disturbance in mental status, often caused by a medical condition, medication, or substance use. The patient's history of <fact2>multiple chronic conditions</fact2> and <fact13>obesity</fact13> further supports this diagnosis. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is {B} Delirium.

question:
A 45-year-old man arrives by ambulance to the emergency room after being involved in a very severe construction accident. The patient was found unconscious with a large metal spike protruding from his abdomen by a coworker who was unable to estimate the amount of time the patient went without medical aid. Upon arrival to the ER, the patient was unconscious and unresponsive. His vital signs are BP: 80/40, HR: 120 bpm, RR: 25 bpm, Temperature: 97.1 degrees, and SPO2: 99%.He is taken to the operating room to remove the foreign body and control the bleeding. Although both objectives were accomplished, the patient had an acute drop in his blood pressure during the surgery at which time ST elevations were noted in multiple leads. This resolved with adequate fluid resuscitation and numerous blood transfusions. The patient remained sedated after surgery and continued to have relatively stable vital signs until his third day in the intensive care unit, when he experiences an oxygen desaturation of 85% despite being on a respirator with 100% oxygen at 15 breaths/minute. On auscultation air entry is present bilaterally with the presence of crackles. A 2/6 systolic murmur is heard. Readings from a Swan-Ganz catheter display the following: central venous pressure (CVP): 4 mmHg, right ventricular pressure (RVP) 20/5 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 20/5 mmHg. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP): 5 mm Hg. A chest x-ray is shown as Image A. The patient dies soon after this episode. What is the most likely direct cause of his death?
A) Diffuse alveolar damage
B) Ventricular septal defect
C) Myocardial free wall rupture
D) Papillary muscle rupture
E) Myocardial reinfarction
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A 45-year-old man arrives by ambulance to the emergency room after being involved in a very severe <fact1>construction accident</fact1>. The patient was found unconscious with a large metal spike protruding from his abdomen by a coworker who was unable to estimate the amount of time the patient went without medical aid. Upon arrival to the ER, the patient was unconscious and unresponsive. His vital signs are BP: 80/40, HR: 120 bpm, RR: 25 bpm, Temperature: 97.1 degrees, and SPO2: 99%.He is taken to the operating room to remove the foreign body and control the bleeding. Although both objectives were accomplished, the patient had an acute drop in his blood pressure during the surgery at which time <fact2>ST elevations were noted in multiple leads</fact2>. This resolved with adequate fluid resuscitation and numerous blood transfusions. The patient remained sedated after surgery and continued to have relatively stable vital signs until his third day in the intensive care unit, when he experiences an <fact3>oxygen desaturation of 85%</fact3> despite being on a respirator with 100% oxygen at 15 breaths/minute. On auscultation air entry is present bilaterally with the presence of <fact4>crackles</fact4>. A 2/6 systolic murmur is heard. Readings from a Swan-Ganz catheter display the following: central venous pressure (CVP): 4 mmHg, right ventricular pressure (RVP) 20/5 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 20/5 mmHg. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP): 5 mm Hg. A chest x-ray is shown as Image A. The patient dies soon after this episode. What is the most likely direct cause of his death?

Answer: 

Analyzing the patient's presentation, the <fact1>construction accident</fact1> and subsequent surgical intervention suggest a high-risk scenario for complications. The patient's initial stability post-surgery was followed by a significant <fact3>oxygen desaturation of 85%</fact3> and the presence of <fact4>crackles</fact4> on auscultation, indicating acute respiratory distress. The Swan-Ganz catheter readings show low CVP and PCWP, which do not support a diagnosis of left heart failure. However, the presence of <fact2>ST elevations in multiple leads</fact2> during surgery suggests myocardial injury. Considering these factors, the most likely direct cause of death is <fact5>diffuse alveolar damage</fact5>, also known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which is a common complication of severe trauma and surgical interventions. The answer is A.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents with painless swelling of the neck over the past week. He also says he has been having intermittent fevers and severe night sweats which require a change of bed sheets the next day. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) diagnosed 10 years ago with which he admits to not always being compliant with his antiretroviral medication. The patient reports a 20-pack-year smoking history but no alcohol or recreational drug use. A review of systems is significant for a 6 kg (13.2 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. The vital signs include: temperature 37.8℃ (100.0℉) and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there are multiple non-tender swollen lymph nodes averaging 2 cm in diameter that is palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. Axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present on the right side. A cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The spleen size is 16 cm on percussion. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 88 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 130,000/mm3
    Serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Serum lactate dehydrogenase 1,000 U/L
An excisional biopsy of a superficial axillary lymph node on the right is performed and a histopathologic analysis confirms the most likely diagnosis. Which of the following is the next best diagnostic step in the workup of this patient?
A) Antinuclear antibody
B) Hepatitis C virus antibodies
C) JAK-2 mutation
D) Peripheral blood flow cytometry
E) Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) test
answer:

The patient reports a <fact6>20-pack-year smoking history</fact6> but no alcohol or recreational drug use. A <fact13>cardiopulmonary exam</fact13> is unremarkable. The <fact14>spleen size is 16 cm on percussion</fact14>. Laboratory studies show the following:
<fact15>Hemoglobin 9 g/dL</fact15>
<fact16>Mean corpuscular volume 88 μm3</fact16>
<fact17>Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Platelet count 130,000/mm3</fact18>
<fact19>Serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Serum lactate dehydrogenase 1,000 U/L</fact20>

E) Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) test

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>painless swelling of the neck</fact2>, <fact3>intermittent fevers and severe night sweats</fact3>, and a history of <fact4>human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)</fact4>, along with significant <fact7>unintentional weight loss</fact7> and <fact10>multiple non-tender swollen lymph nodes</fact10>, a lymphoproliferative disorder is suspected. The <fact21>excisional biopsy of a superficial axillary lymph node</fact21> and <fact22>histopathologic analysis</fact22> likely indicate lymphoma. Given the patient's HIV status and the need to further characterize the lymphoma, <fact5>non-compliance with antiretroviral medication</fact5> is a concern. However, to confirm the specific type of lymphoma and guide treatment, the next best diagnostic step would be to perform <fact23>Peripheral blood flow cytometry</fact23> to assess for specific lymphocyte markers. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 50-year-old man presents to his physician with chronic cough, aching joints in his hips and lower back, and malaise over the past 2 months. He describes himself as being “generally healthy” before the cough began. Past medical history includes hypertension. The patient takes clopamide and a multivitamin daily. His parents are both well and living in a senior living facility. He does not smoke and only drinks alcohol occasionally. During a review of symptoms, the patient described a hiking trip in and around the desert near Phoenix, Arizona, 4 months ago. At the office, his temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), heart rate is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/82 mm Hg. A focused chest exam reveals mild fremetus and dullness with percussion on the right side. A chest X-ray shows a right-sided consolidation of the lower right lung, and a chest CT shows an irregular opacity measuring 3.8 cm x 3.0 cm in the sub-plural region of the right middle lobe, a small right-sided pleural effusion, and mild right-sided hilar adenopathy. A lung biopsy is performed to rule out cancer and reveals necrotic granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells and spherules with endospores in the surrounding tissues. The laboratory tests show the following results:
Hemoglobin 12.9 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 9,300/mm3
Platelet count 167,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 43 mm/hr
Periodic acid-Schiff and silver methenamine Positive
Acid-fast stain Negative
 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Histoplasmosis
B) Mycetoma
C) Blastomycosis
D) Valley fever
E) Chromomycosis
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>50-year-old man</fact1> presents to his physician with <fact2>chronic cough, aching joints in his hips and lower back, and malaise</fact2> over the past <fact3>2 months</fact3>. He describes himself as being “generally healthy” before the cough began. Past medical history includes <fact4>hypertension</fact4>. The patient takes <fact5>clopamide and a multivitamin daily</fact5>. His parents are both well and living in a senior living facility. He does not smoke and only drinks alcohol occasionally. During a review of symptoms, the patient described a <fact6>hiking trip in and around the desert near Phoenix, Arizona, 4 months ago</fact6>. At the office, his <fact7>temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F)</fact7>, <fact8>heart rate is 102/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 20/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 120/82 mm Hg</fact10>. A focused chest exam reveals <fact11>mild fremetus and dullness with percussion on the right side</fact11>. A <fact12>chest X-ray shows a right-sided consolidation of the lower right lung</fact12>, and a <fact13>chest CT shows an irregular opacity measuring 3.8 cm x 3.0 cm in the sub-plural region of the right middle lobe, a small right-sided pleural effusion, and mild right-sided hilar adenopathy</fact13>. A <fact14>lung biopsy is performed to rule out cancer</fact14> and reveals <fact15>necrotic granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells and spherules with endospores in the surrounding tissues</fact15>. The laboratory tests show the following results:
Hemoglobin <fact16>12.9 mg/dL</fact16>
Leukocyte count <fact17>9,300/mm3</fact17>
Platelet count <fact18>167,000/mm3</fact18>

Periodic acid-Schiff and silver methenamine <fact20>Positive</fact20>
Acid-fast stain <fact21>Negative</fact21>
