Answer:

Considering the <fact1>50-year-old man's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>chronic cough, aching joints in his hips and lower back, and malaise</fact2> over the past <fact3>2 months</fact3>, along with the <fact6>hiking trip in and around the desert near Phoenix, Arizona, 4 months ago</fact6>, suggests exposure to a specific pathogen. The <fact7>temperature of 38.6°C (101.4°F)</fact7>, <fact8>heart rate of 102/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations of 20/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure of 120/82 mm Hg</fact10> indicate a systemic infection. The <fact11>mild fremetus and dullness with percussion on the right side</fact11> found during the chest exam, along with the <fact12>chest X-ray and chest CT findings</fact12>, suggest a pulmonary infection. The <fact14>lung biopsy</fact14> revealing <fact15>necrotic granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells and spherules with endospores in the surrounding tissues</fact15> is highly indicative of a fungal infection. The laboratory results showing <fact20>positive Periodic acid-Schiff and silver methenamine</fact20> and <fact21>negative Acid-fast stain</fact21> further support this diagnosis. Given these findings, the most likely diagnosis is Valley fever, caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis, which is endemic in the desert regions of the southwestern United States, including Arizona. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with a fever. She developed worsening malaise and diaphoresis over the past 48 hours. Her maximum temperature was 102°F (38.9°C) taken the night before presentation. Her past medical history is notable for major depressive disorder, obesity, fibromyalgia, and severe tension headaches. She previously took paroxetine for a 2-month trial but switched to citalopram 6 months ago as she did not feel like paroxetine was adequately helping her symptoms. Her mood has been stable on her current dose of citalopram. She takes ibuprofen for her headaches but previously borrowed a friend’s headache medication when her headaches became very severe. Of note, she has been trying to lose weight and recently started taking an amino acid supplement at the suggestion of her nephew who is a nutritionist. She is also trying out a new low-carbohydrate diet. She works as a nurse at a local primary care clinic. Her temperature is 101.5°F (38.6°C), blood pressure is 144/80 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 22/min. She is diaphoretic and shivering. Patellar and brachioradialis reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Tone is increased in her bilateral upper and lower extremities. Rapid dorsiflexion of her right ankle elicits 3 beats of clonus. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light. A basic metabolic panel is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely inciting factor for this patient’s condition?
A) Decreased carbohydrate intake
B) Increased tryptophan intake
C) Medication change
D) Surreptitious diuretic abuse
E) Surreptitious opiate abuse
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>34-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency room with a <fact2>fever</fact2>. She developed <fact3>worsening malaise and diaphoresis</fact3> over the past <fact4>48 hours</fact4>. Her maximum <fact5>temperature was 102°F (38.9°C)</fact5> taken the night before presentation. Her past medical history is notable for <fact6>major depressive disorder, obesity, fibromyalgia, and severe tension headaches</fact6>. She previously took <fact7>paroxetine</fact7> for a <fact8>2-month trial</fact8> but switched to <fact9>citalopram 6 months ago</fact9> as she did not feel like <fact7>paroxetine</fact7> was adequately helping her symptoms. Her mood has been stable on her current dose of <fact9>citalopram</fact9>. She takes <fact10>ibuprofen</fact10> for her headaches but previously borrowed a friend’s <fact11>headache medication</fact11> when her headaches became very severe. Of note, she has been trying to lose weight and recently started taking an <fact12>amino acid supplement</fact12> at the suggestion of her nephew who is a nutritionist. She is also trying out a new <fact13>low-carbohydrate diet</fact13>. She works as a nurse at a local primary care clinic. Her <fact14>temperature is 101.5°F (38.6°C)</fact14>, <fact15>blood pressure is 144/80 mmHg</fact15>, <fact16>pulse is 108/min</fact16>, and <fact17>respirations are 22/min</fact17>. She is <fact18>diaphoretic and shivering</fact18>. Patellar and brachioradialis reflexes are <fact19>3+ bilaterally</fact19>. Tone is increased in her bilateral upper and lower extremities. Rapid dorsiflexion of her right ankle elicits <fact20>3 beats of clonus</fact20>. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light. A basic metabolic panel is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely inciting factor for this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Based on the patient's symptoms of <fact3>worsening malaise and diaphoresis</fact3>, <fact18>diaphoretic and shivering</fact18>, increased tone in her bilateral upper and lower extremities, and <fact20>3 beats of clonus</fact20> upon rapid dorsiflexion of her right ankle, it is likely that the patient is experiencing serotonin syndrome. This condition is often caused by excessive levels of serotonin in the body, which can be due to the use of certain medications or supplements. Given that the patient recently started taking an <fact12>amino acid supplement</fact12> and has been taking <fact9>citalopram</fact9> for her major depressive disorder, the combination of these two may have led to excessive serotonin levels. However, the most likely inciting factor is the <fact12>amino acid supplement</fact12>, which may contain tryptophan, an amino acid that is converted into serotonin in the body. Therefore, the correct answer is {B} Increased tryptophan intake.

question:
An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a 33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2) from an uncomplicated pregnancy at 39 weeks. He has met all developmental milestones and is up to date on all vaccinations. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 137/min, respiratory rate 25/min, and temperature 36.7°C (97.0°F). His length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile. On physical examination, blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae are noted. Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits for his age. There is joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the tough. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician palpates his leg. The patient’s X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
A) Child abuse
B) Insufficient production of procollagen type 1
C) Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1
D) Defective collagen type 3
E) Dysfunctional structure of laminins
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>11-month-old male infant</fact1> is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a <fact2>33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2)</fact2> from an uncomplicated pregnancy at <fact3>39 weeks</fact3>. He has met all developmental milestones and is up to date on all vaccinations. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair <fact4>2 days ago</fact4>. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure <fact5>80/40 mm Hg</fact5>, heart rate <fact6>137/min</fact6>, respiratory rate <fact7>25/min</fact7>, and temperature <fact8>36.7°C (97.0°F)</fact8>. His length and weight are both between the <fact9>15th and 25th percentile</fact9>. On physical examination, <fact10>blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae</fact10> are noted. Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits for his age. There is <fact11>joint hypermobility</fact11> and <fact12>decreased tone</fact12> in both upper and lower extremities. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the tough. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician palpates his leg. The patient’s X-ray shows an <fact13>incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis</fact13>. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact10>blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae</fact10>, <fact11>joint hypermobility</fact11>, and <fact12>decreased tone</fact12> in both upper and lower extremities, along with the <fact13>incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis</fact13> after a relatively minor trauma (<fact4>hitting his right leg against a chair 2 days ago</fact4>), the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is a condition affecting bone fragility and collagen production. Among the options provided, the insufficient production of procollagen type 1, which is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta, is the most plausible explanation. This condition is characterized by fragile bones, blue sclerae, and joint hypermobility, all of which are present in the patient. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. His abdominal discomfort is worse shortly after meals. He has also had progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping for the past 24 hours. Six months ago, he underwent a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass to treat obesity. He underwent a total thyroidectomy to treat a Hurthle cell lesion 4 days ago. His mother died of lung cancer at age 68. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. His only current medication is a multivitamin supplement. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. While measuring the patient's blood pressure, the nurse observes spasm of the patient's hand. Physical examination shows a well-healing surgical wound on the neck. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation with well-healed laparoscopic incisional sites. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 138 mEq/L
K+ 4.2 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 25 mEq/L
Mg2+ 1.7 mEq/L
Phosphorus 4.3 mg/dL
25-hydroxyvitamin D 20 ng/mL (N: 20-100 ng/mL)
Parathyroid hormone 115 pg/mL
Total bilirubin, serum 0.7 mg/dL
Alanine aminotransferase, serum 14 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase, serum 15 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase, serum 42 U/L
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?"
A) Obtain abdominal CT
B) Observation only
C) Begin rehydration therapy
D) Administer calcium gluconate
E) Supplementation with vitamin D
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>41-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department with <fact2>nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea</fact2> for the past <fact3>2 days</fact3>. His <fact4>abdominal discomfort is worse shortly after meals</fact4>. He has also had <fact5>progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping</fact5> for the past <fact6>24 hours</fact6>. <fact7>Six months ago, he underwent a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass</fact7> to treat obesity. He underwent a <fact8>total thyroidectomy</fact8> to treat a Hurthle cell lesion <fact9>4 days ago</fact9>. His mother died of lung cancer at age <fact10>68</fact10>. He has <fact11>smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years</fact11>. His only current medication is a <fact12>multivitamin supplement</fact12>. He appears <fact13>fatigued</fact13>. His temperature is <fact14>36°C (96.8°F)</fact14>, pulse is <fact15>72/min</fact15>, respirations are <fact16>20/min</fact16>, and blood pressure is <fact17>130/70 mm Hg</fact17>. While measuring the patient's blood pressure, the nurse observes <fact18>spasm of the patient's hand</fact18>. Physical examination shows a <fact19>well-healing surgical wound on the neck</fact19>. The abdomen is <fact20>mildly tender to palpation</fact20> with <fact21>well-healed laparoscopic incisional sites</fact21>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ <fact22>138 mEq/L</fact22>
K+ <fact23>4.2 mEq/L</fact23>
Cl- <fact24>102 mEq/L</fact24>
HCO3- <fact25>25 mEq/L</fact25>
Mg2+ <fact26>1.7 mEq/L</fact26>
Phosphorus <fact27>4.3 mg/dL</fact27>
25-hydroxyvitamin D <fact28>20 ng/mL</fact28> (N: 20-100 ng/mL)
Parathyroid hormone <fact29>115 pg/mL</fact29>
Total bilirubin, serum <fact30>0.7 mg/dL</fact30>
Alanine aminotransferase, serum <fact31>14 U/L</fact31>
Aspartate aminotransferase, serum <fact32>15 U/L</fact32>
Alkaline phosphatase, serum <fact33>42 U/L</fact33>
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea</fact2>, along with <fact5>progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping</fact5>, and the recent history of <fact8>total thyroidectomy</fact8> <fact9>4 days ago</fact9>, hypocalcemia is a likely complication. The serum studies show a low Mg2+ level of <fact26>1.7 mEq/L</fact26> and a high Parathyroid hormone level of <fact29>115 pg/mL</fact29>, which is indicative of hypocalcemia. The observed <fact18>spasm of the patient's hand</fact18> during blood pressure measurement further supports this diagnosis. Therefore, the most appropriate initial step in management is to administer calcium gluconate to correct the hypocalcemia. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?
A) Isoniazid
B) Fluconazole
C) Caspofungin
D) Prednisone
E) Surgical resection of the infiltrates
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> with a <fact2>history of asthma</fact2> visits her physician for <fact3>worsening shortness of breath</fact3>. She states that she feels as though her “<fact4>lungs are falling apart</fact4>,” noting that her <fact5>lung function has been steadily deteriorating</fact5>. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her <fact6>asthma exacerbations</fact6>. She has experienced <fact7>4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years</fact7> and often suffers from “<fact8>random</fact8>” bouts of excessive <fact9>coughing and wheezing</fact9>. When asked if her <fact10>coughing episodes produce sputum</fact10>, she states, “Yes, the stuff is <fact11>greenish with specks of red in it</fact11>.” She also states that her <fact12>coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact12>. The vital signs include: <fact13>blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg</fact13>, <fact14>pulse 66/min</fact14>, <fact15>respiratory rate 26/min</fact15>, and <fact16>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact16>. On physical exam, the patient appears <fact17>frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress</fact17>. Auscultation reveals <fact18>inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes</fact18>. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals <fact19>atelectasis in the right lung base</fact19>. There are also <fact20>branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows”</fact20> (noted by the arrow in the image). <fact21>Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated</fact21>. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?

Answer: The patient's presentation, including <fact5>steadily deteriorating lung function</fact5>, <fact7>repeated episodes of pneumonia</fact7>, <fact9>coughing and wheezing</fact9>, <fact11>greenish sputum with specks of red</fact11>, and <fact12>fever, malaise, and expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact12>, along with <fact21>elevated serum IgE levels</fact21>, suggests a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). The chest radiograph findings of <fact19>atelectasis</fact19> and <fact20>“glove-finger shadows”</fact20> are also consistent with ABPA. In this context, the most appropriate therapy is prednisone, a corticosteroid that can help reduce inflammation and manage symptoms. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
An 81-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son to be evaluated for memory issues. The patient’s son says he has difficulty remembering recent events and names. He says the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the last several years but became acutely worse just recently. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that he could not see out of his right eye, but today he can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. His medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. He had a left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago and a right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, sitagliptin, and valsartan. He lives with his son and can feed himself and change his clothes. There is no history of urinary or fecal incontinence. His vitals include: blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. He is unable to perform simple arithmetic calculations and the mini-mental status exam is inconclusive. He can write his name and comprehend written instructions. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with exaggerated reflexes. His gait is hemiparetic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Alzheimer's disease
B) Frontotemporal dementia
C) Lewy body dementia
D) Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
E) Vascular dementia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

An <fact1>81-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the clinic by his son to be evaluated for <fact2>memory issues</fact2>. The patient’s son says he has difficulty <fact3>remembering recent events and names</fact3>. He says the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the last several years but became acutely worse just recently. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that he could not see out of his right eye, but today he can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. His medical history is significant for <fact4>diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension</fact4>. He had a <fact5>left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago and a right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago</fact5>. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, sitagliptin, and valsartan. He lives with his son and can feed himself and change his clothes. There is no history of urinary or fecal incontinence. His vitals include: blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. He is unable to perform simple arithmetic calculations and the mini-mental status exam is inconclusive. He can write his name and comprehend written instructions. Muscle strength is <fact6>4/5 on the right side</fact6>. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with exaggerated reflexes. His gait is hemiparetic.

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>memory issues</fact2> with difficulty <fact3>remembering recent events and names</fact3>, along with a history of <fact5>previous strokes</fact5> (left basal ganglia hemorrhage and right middle cerebral artery infarction), and current physical examination findings such as <fact6>reduced muscle strength on the right side</fact6> and a hemiparetic gait, are highly suggestive of vascular dementia. Vascular dementia is a type of dementia that is caused by reduced blood flow to the brain, often as a result of a series of small strokes or changes in the brain's blood supply. The patient's medical history of <fact4>diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension</fact4> also increases his risk for vascular dementia. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is {E}.

question:
A 14-year-old obese boy presents with severe right hip and knee pain. The patient says that he has been limping with mild pain for the past three weeks, but the pain acutely worsened today. He describes the pain as severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character, and localized to the right hip and knee joints. The patient denies recent illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past. No significant past medical history and no current medications. The patient is not sexually active and denies any alcohol, smoking or drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The right leg is externally rotated, and there is a limited range of motion in the right hip. Strength is 4 out of 5 at the right hip joint and 5 out of 5 elsewhere. There is no tenderness to palpation. No joint erythema, edema or effusion present. Sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory tests are unremarkable. Plain radiographs of the right hip joint are significant for displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient?
A) Reassess in 3 months
B) Immobilize the right knee with conservative treatment (i.e. rest, ice)
C) Intra-articular corticosteroid injection of the right hip joint
D) Pavlik harness
E) Surgical pinning of the right hip
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old obese boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>severe right hip and knee pain</fact2>. The patient says that he has been <fact3>limping with mild pain for the past three weeks</fact3>, but the <fact4>pain acutely worsened today</fact4>. He describes the pain as <fact5>severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character, and localized to the right hip and knee joints</fact5>. The patient denies <fact6>recent illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past</fact6>. No significant <fact7>past medical history</fact7> and no current <fact8>medications</fact8>. The patient is not <fact9>sexually active</fact9> and denies any <fact10>alcohol, smoking or drug use</fact10>. The vital signs include: <fact11>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact11>, <fact12>blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg</fact12>, <fact13>pulse 72/min</fact13>, <fact14>respiratory rate 15/min</fact14>, and <fact15>oxygen saturation 99% on room air</fact15>. <fact16>Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2</fact16>. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The <fact17>right leg is externally rotated</fact17>, and there is a <fact18>limited range of motion in the right hip</fact18>. <fact19>Strength is 4 out of 5 at the right hip joint and 5 out of 5 elsewhere</fact19>. There is no <fact20>tenderness to palpation</fact20>. No <fact21>joint erythema, edema or effusion present</fact21>. <fact22>Sensation is intact</fact22>. <fact23>Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally</fact23>. Laboratory tests are <fact24>unremarkable</fact24>. Plain radiographs of the right hip joint are significant for <fact25>displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck</fact25>. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact25>displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck</fact25> observed in the radiographs, along with the symptoms of <fact2>severe right hip and knee pain</fact2> and the physical examination findings such as the <fact17>right leg is externally rotated</fact17> and <fact18>limited range of motion in the right hip</fact18>, the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient would be surgical intervention to correct the femoral head displacement. Among the provided options, {E} Surgical pinning of the right hip is the most appropriate course of treatment. This procedure will help to stabilize the femoral head, alleviate pain, and prevent further complications.

question:
A 63-year-old man from the countryside presents with leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He reports a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is aspirin. He also stated that he used to have ‘high blood sugars’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a farmer and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of fatigue and syncope. He has a 24-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, the patient is pale and acrocyanotic. There is a visible jugular vein distention and bilateral lower leg pitting edema. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for occasional bilateral wheezes. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of ascites. The hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?
A) Left ventricular ejection fraction of 41%
B) Increased peak tricuspid regurgitation
C) Hypokinetic wall of the left ventricle
D) Abnormal left ventricular relaxation
E) Decreased right atrial pressure
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> from the countryside presents with <fact2>leg swelling</fact2> and <fact3>right upper abdominal tenderness</fact3>. He reports a history of <fact4>myocardial infarction 4 years ago</fact4>, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is <fact5>aspirin</fact5>. He also stated that he used to have ‘<fact6>high blood sugars</fact6>’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a <fact7>farmer</fact7> and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of <fact8>fatigue</fact8> and <fact9>syncope</fact9>. He has a <fact10>24-pack-year history of smoking</fact10> and consumes <fact11>alcohol occasionally</fact11>. The vital signs include: <fact12>blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg</fact12>, <fact13>heart rate 83/min</fact13>, <fact14>respiratory rate 16/min</fact14>, and <fact15>temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉)</fact15>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact16>pale and acrocyanotic</fact16>. There is a <fact17>visible jugular vein distention</fact17> and <fact18>bilateral lower leg pitting edema</fact18>. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for <fact19>occasional bilateral wheezes</fact19>. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a <fact20>decreased S1</fact20>, <fact21>S3 gallop</fact21>, and <fact22>grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space</fact22>. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of <fact23>ascites</fact23>. The hepatic margin is <fact24>3 cm below the right costal margin</fact24>. Hepatojugular reflux is <fact25>positive</fact25>. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact4>myocardial infarction 4 years ago</fact4> and the current symptoms of <fact2>leg swelling</fact2>, <fact3>right upper abdominal tenderness</fact3>, <fact8>fatigue</fact8>, and <fact9>syncope</fact9>, along with physical examination findings of <fact16>pale and acrocyanotic</fact16> appearance, <fact17>visible jugular vein distention</fact17>, <fact18>bilateral lower leg pitting edema</fact18>, and <fact23>ascites</fact23>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing heart failure. The presence of a <fact21>S3 gallop</fact21> and <fact22>grade 3/6 systolic murmur</fact22> on cardiac auscultation further supports this diagnosis. An echocardiogram would likely show a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), indicating systolic dysfunction. Therefore, the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram is a <fact26>left ventricular ejection fraction of 41%</fact26>, which is below the normal range of 55% or higher. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of worsening abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She reports nausea and vomiting and is unable to tolerate oral intake. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), the pulse is 92/min, the respirations are 18/min, and the blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows yellowish discoloration of her sclera. Her abdomen is tender in the right upper quadrant. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly. The laboratory tests show the following results:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 432 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 196 U/L
Aspartate transaminase 207 U/L
Bilirubin  
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 2.7 mg/dL
Lipase 82 U/L
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts and multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder. The pancreas is not well visualized. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole are initiated. After 12 hours, the patient appears acutely ill and is not oriented to time. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), the pulse is 105/min, the respirations are 22/min, and the blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan
B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
D) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
E) Percutaneous cholecystostomy
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>58-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency department because of <fact2>worsening abdominal pain</fact2> for the past 2 days. She reports <fact3>nausea and vomiting</fact3> and is unable to tolerate oral intake. She appears uncomfortable. Her <fact4>temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F)</fact4>, the <fact5>pulse is 92/min</fact5>, the <fact6>respirations are 18/min</fact6>, and the <fact7>blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg</fact7>. Physical examination shows <fact8>yellowish discoloration of her sclera</fact8>. Her abdomen is <fact9>tender in the right upper quadrant</fact9>. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly. The laboratory tests show the following results:
<fact10>Hemoglobin 13 g/dL</fact10>
<fact11>Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3</fact11>
<fact12>Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL</fact12>
<fact13>Creatinine 2 mg/dL</fact13>
<fact14>Alkaline phosphatase 432 U/L</fact14>
<fact15>Alanine aminotransferase 196 U/L</fact15>
<fact16>Aspartate transaminase 207 U/L</fact16>
<fact17>Bilirubin</fact17>  
<fact18>Total 3.8 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Direct 2.7 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Lipase 82 U/L</fact20>
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows <fact21>dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts</fact21> and <fact22>multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder</fact22>. The pancreas is not well visualized. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole are initiated. After 12 hours, the patient appears acutely ill and is not oriented to time. Her <fact23>temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F)</fact23>, the <fact24>pulse is 105/min</fact24>, the <fact25>respirations are 22/min</fact25>, and the <fact26>blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg</fact26>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the patient's condition has worsened despite initial treatment with intravenous fluids and antibiotics, as indicated by her increased <fact23>temperature</fact23>, elevated <fact24>pulse</fact24>, and increased <fact25>respirations</fact25>. The presence of <fact8>yellowish discoloration of her sclera</fact8> and <fact9>tender abdomen in the right upper quadrant</fact9> suggests a biliary obstruction, which is confirmed by the ultrasound findings of <fact21>dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts</fact21> and <fact22>multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder</fact22>. Given the patient's deteriorating condition and the need for prompt intervention to relieve the obstruction, the most appropriate next step in management is to perform an <fact27>endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)</fact27> to clear the obstruction and allow for proper bile drainage. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with nausea, vomiting, fever, and pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen for the past 18 hours. He mentions that he has been experiencing intermittent episodes of pain at the same location over the last 3 months and that these episodes usually occur after a heavy meal and subside within 1 or 2 hours. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On examination of the abdomen, tenderness is present over the right upper quadrant; palpation over the area produces an inspiratory pause. An urgent bedside ultrasonogram shows a dilated common bile duct stone, but no stone in the common bile duct or in the gallbladder. Laboratory results show the following:
Hemoglobin 15.4 g/dL (9.56 mmol/L)
Total leukocyte count 14,000/mm3 (17.4 x 10*9/L)
Segmented neutrophils 70%
Lymphocytes 25%
Monocytes 4%
Eosinophils 1%
Basophils 0%
Platelet count 32,0000/mm3 (320 x 10*9/L)
Serum bilirubin (total) 1.8 mg/dL (30.78 μmol/L)
Serum bilirubin (direct) 1.1 mg/dL (18.81 μmol/L)
Serum alanine aminotransferase 96 U/L
Serum aspartate aminotransferase 88 U/L
Serum alkaline phosphatase
350 U/L (5.83 μkat/L)
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Urgent laparoscopic cholecystectomy
B) Medical management followed by elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy
C) Medical management followed by elective open cholecystectomy
D) Urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ECRP)
E) Cholecystotomy
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>48-year-old man</fact1> presents to the clinic with <fact2>nausea, vomiting, fever, and pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen</fact2> for the past <fact3>18 hours</fact3>. He mentions that he has been experiencing <fact4>intermittent episodes of pain at the same location</fact4> over the last <fact5>3 months</fact5> and that these episodes usually occur <fact6>after a heavy meal</fact6> and subside within <fact7>1 or 2 hours</fact7>. On physical examination, his <fact8>temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 130/min</fact9>, <fact10>respirations are 24/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg</fact11>. On examination of the abdomen, <fact12>tenderness is present over the right upper quadrant</fact12>; palpation over the area produces an <fact13>inspiratory pause</fact13>. An urgent bedside <fact14>ultrasonogram shows a dilated common bile duct stone</fact14>, but no stone in the common bile duct or in the gallbladder. Laboratory results show the following:
Hemoglobin 15.4 g/dL (9.56 mmol/L)
Total leukocyte count 14,000/mm3 (17.4 x 10*9/L)
Segmented neutrophils 70%
Lymphocytes 25%
Monocytes 4%
Eosinophils 1%
Basophils 0%
Platelet count 320,000/mm3 (320 x 10*9/L)
Serum bilirubin (total) 1.8 mg/dL (30.78 μmol/L)
Serum bilirubin (direct) 1.1 mg/dL (18.81 μmol/L)
Serum alanine aminotransferase 96 U/L
Serum aspartate aminotransferase 88 U/L
Serum alkaline phosphatase 350 U/L (5.83 μkat/L)
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer:

Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>nausea, vomiting, fever, and pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen</fact2> and the laboratory results, the most likely diagnosis is cholangitis, which is an infection of the bile duct. The presence of a <fact14>dilated common bile duct stone</fact14> and the patient's symptoms suggest that the stone is causing an obstruction, leading to infection. Given the patient's <fact8>fever</fact8>, <fact9>elevated pulse</fact9>, and <fact10>increased respirations</fact10>, indicating a possible sepsis, the most appropriate next step in management would be to relieve the obstruction and clear the infection. Therefore, the correct answer is {D} <fact14>Urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)</fact14>, which is a procedure used to diagnose and treat problems in the bile and pancreatic ducts, including removing stones and relieving obstructions.

question:
A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 ml of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:
Erythrocyte count 1/mm3
Leukocyte count 4,000/mm3
Glucose 59 mg/dl
Lactate dehydrogenase 248 U/L
Protein 3.8 g/dL
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?"
A) Bronchial adenocarcinoma
B) Mesothelioma
C) Nephrotic syndrome
D) Tuberculosis
E) Congestive heart failure
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>79-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue</fact2>. During this period, she also has had a <fact3>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss</fact3> and has become increasingly <fact4>short of breath with mild exertion</fact4>. She has <fact5>congestive heart failure</fact5> and <fact6>hypertension</fact6>. Three months ago, she was in <fact7>India</fact7> for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a <fact8>seamstress in a textile factory</fact8> for 50 years. She has <fact9>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years</fact9>. Her current medications include <fact10>enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol</fact10>. She appears thin. Her temperature is <fact11>37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact11>, pulse is <fact12>90/min</fact12>, respirations are <fact13>25/min</fact13>, and blood pressure is <fact14>110/70 mm Hg</fact14>. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of <fact15>94%</fact15>. There is <fact16>dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact16>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of <fact17>90 mg/dL</fact17>, serum lactate dehydrogenase of <fact18>227 U/L</fact18>, and serum protein of <fact19>6.3 g/dL</fact19>. An x-ray of the chest shows <fact20>nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion</fact20>. Thoracentesis shows 250 ml of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:
Erythrocyte count <fact21>1/mm3</fact21>
Leukocyte count <fact22>4,000/mm3</fact22>
Glucose <fact23>59 mg/dl</fact23>
Lactate dehydrogenase <fact24>248 U/L</fact24>
Protein <fact25>3.8 g/dL</fact25>
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>non-productive cough and fatigue</fact2>, <fact3>weight loss</fact3>, and <fact4>shortness of breath</fact4>, along with her history of <fact5>congestive heart failure</fact5> and <fact6>hypertension</fact6>, it is essential to evaluate the pleural effusion in the context of her overall health. However, the presence of <fact20>nodular pleural lesions on the right side</fact20> and the characteristics of the pleural fluid aspirate, such as a high lactate dehydrogenase level (<fact24>248 U/L</fact24>) and a protein level of <fact25>3.8 g/dL</fact25>, suggest an exudative process rather than a transudative one, which is typically seen in congestive heart failure. Given her long history of <fact9>smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years</fact9> and her occupation as a <fact8>seamstress in a textile factory</fact8> for 50 years, which may expose her to asbestos, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion is <fact26>Mesothelioma</fact26>. The answer is {B}.

question:
An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about two weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds. She reports that he seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Initiate proton pump inhibitor
B) Obtain abdominal ultrasound
C) Reassurance and counseling on positioning
D) Recommend modification of mother’s diet
E) Switch to hydrolyzed formula
answer:
Reformatted Question:

An <fact1>8-week-old male</fact1> presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been <fact2>breastfed since birth</fact2>, and usually feeds for <fact3>30 minutes every 2-3 hours</fact3>. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about <fact4>two weeks ago</fact4> the patient began <fact5>regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds</fact5>. She reports that he seems <fact6>mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation</fact6> but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried <fact7>limiting the volume of each feed</fact7>, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any <fact8>diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies</fact8>. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around <fact9>12 months of age</fact9>. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the <fact10>40th and 34th percentiles, respectively</fact10>. His height and weight are now respectively in the <fact11>37th and 36th percentiles</fact11>. On physical exam, the patient is <fact12>cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her</fact12>. He <fact13>lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position</fact13>. His abdomen is <fact14>soft, non-tender and non-distended</fact14>. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, the key points are that the patient is <fact1>8-week-old</fact1> and has been <fact2>breastfed since birth</fact2> with a recent onset of <fact5>regurgitating breastmilk</fact5> that has been managed by <fact7>limiting the volume of each feed</fact7>, with no signs of severe illness or distress (<fact6>mildly upset</fact6>, <fact12>cooing and smiling</fact12>, and <fact14>soft, non-tender abdomen</fact14>). Additionally, the patient's growth percentiles have not significantly declined (<fact10>40th to 37th</fact10> and <fact11>34th to 36th</fact11> percentiles). Given these factors, the most appropriate next step is to provide <fact15>reassurance and counseling on positioning</fact15>, as this is a common and often self-limiting condition. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain that is not affected by eating. He reports that over the last 6 months he slept a lot more than usual and lost 14.9 kg (33 lbs) without trying to lose weight. He also complains of chest pain and shortness of breath that is worse when he is working and in the yard. There is no significant family history. His long-standing male partner passed away 2 years ago in a fatal car accident. His blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg, the pulse is 90/min, the respiratory rate is 23/min, and the temperature is 38°C (100.5°F). On physical examination, he has pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities. There is a new-onset high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border. His head bobs with each heartbeat. There are small, painless, red macules on both palms. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. His laboratory results are shown below.
Hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 72 µm3
Platelet count 400,000/mm3
Leukocytes 6,000/mm3
Serum ferritin 8 ng/mL
Serum iron 27 µg/dL
Total iron-binding capacity 450 µg/dL
Colonoscopy with biopsy is later performed showing a neoplastic growth in the descending colon. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings?
A) Viridans streptococci
B) Treponema pallidum
C) Malignant colonic neoplasm
D) Collagen vascular disease
E) Group D streptococci
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a <fact2>low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain</fact2> that is not affected by eating. He reports that over the last <fact3>6 months</fact3> he slept a lot more than usual and lost <fact4>14.9 kg (33 lbs)</fact4> without trying to lose weight. He also complains of <fact5>chest pain and shortness of breath</fact5> that is worse when he is working and in the yard. There is no significant family history. His long-standing male partner passed away <fact6>2 years ago</fact6> in a fatal car accident. His <fact7>blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg</fact7>, the <fact8>pulse is 90/min</fact8>, the <fact9>respiratory rate is 23/min</fact9>, and the <fact10>temperature is 38°C (100.5°F)</fact10>. On physical examination, he has <fact11>pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities</fact11>. There is a <fact12>new-onset high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur</fact12> best heard over the <fact13>right upper sternal border</fact13>. His <fact14>head bobs with each heartbeat</fact14>. There are <fact15>small, painless, red macules on both palms</fact15>. His <fact16>spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin</fact16>. His laboratory results are shown below.
Hemoglobin <fact17>8.4 g/dL</fact17>
Mean corpuscular volume <fact18>72 µm3</fact18>
Platelet count <fact19>400,000/mm3</fact19>
Leukocytes <fact20>6,000/mm3</fact20>
Serum ferritin <fact21>8 ng/mL</fact21>
Serum iron <fact22>27 µg/dL</fact22>
Total iron-binding capacity <fact23>450 µg/dL</fact23>
Colonoscopy with biopsy is later performed showing a <fact24>neoplastic growth in the descending colon</fact24>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings?

Answer: The patient's cardiac findings, specifically the <fact12>new-onset high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur</fact12> best heard over the <fact13>right upper sternal border</fact13> and the <fact14>head bobbing with each heartbeat</fact14>, suggest a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. Given the patient's <fact24>neoplastic growth in the descending colon</fact24>, it is likely that the bacterial infection causing endocarditis originated from the gastrointestinal tract. Among the options provided, choice E, Group D streptococci, is a common cause of endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying gastrointestinal disease. The presence of <fact11>pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities</fact11> and the laboratory results showing <fact17>anemia</fact17>, <fact19>thrombocytosis</fact19>, and <fact21>low serum ferritin</fact21> further support this diagnosis. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days. The vomitus consists of undigested food and he has also had dark brown emesis twice today. He has been having early satiety during this period. He has had progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week. The pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. He has also had a weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a tympanitic mass in the epigastrium. A succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips. Bowel sounds are reduced. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 3.3 mEq/L
Cl- 97 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Glucose 77 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?"
A) Inflammation and edema
B) Abnormal gastric rotation
C) Neoplastic growth
D) Scarring and fibrosis
E) Walled-off pancreatic fluid collection
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days</fact2>. The <fact3>vomitus consists of undigested food</fact3> and he has also had <fact4>dark brown emesis twice today</fact4>. He has been having <fact5>early satiety during this period</fact5>. He has had <fact6>progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week</fact6>. The <fact7>pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating</fact7>. He has also had a <fact8>weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period</fact8>. His <fact9>father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago</fact9>. He has <fact10>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years</fact10>. He drinks <fact11>two to three beers daily</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 106/min</fact13> and <fact14>blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg</fact14>. Examination shows <fact15>dry mucous membranes</fact15>. The <fact16>abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant</fact16>; there is a <fact17>tympanitic mass in the epigastrium</fact17>. A <fact18>succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips</fact18>. <fact19>Bowel sounds are reduced</fact19>. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for <fact20>occult blood is positive</fact20>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 3.3 mEq/L
Cl- 97 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Glucose 77 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?

Answer: Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days</fact2> with <fact3>vomitus consisting of undigested food</fact3> and <fact4>dark brown emesis</fact4>, along with <fact6>progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia</fact6> that is <fact7>partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating</fact7>, it suggests a gastric outlet obstruction. The presence of a <fact17>tympanitic mass in the epigastrium</fact17> and a <fact18>succussion splash</fact18> further supports this diagnosis. The most likely underlying cause of this patient's vomiting is <fact20>occult bleeding</fact20> due to a gastric ulcer, which can lead to scarring and fibrosis, causing gastric outlet obstruction. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasingly severe abdominal pain, nausea, and bilious vomiting. His last bowel movement was yesterday and he has not passed flatus since then. He underwent appendectomy at the age of 39. He has psoriasis, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. He drinks two beers daily. He takes a topical corticosteroid, ramipril, metformin, and ibuprofen daily. He is 176 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 108 kg (240 lb); BMI is 35.4 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), respirations are 15/min, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 112/67 mm Hg. Examination shows thick, scaly, plaques over both elbows and knees. Abdominal examination shows three well-healed laparoscopic scars. The abdomen is distended and there are frequent, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation. Digital rectal examination shows an empty rectum. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 44%
Leukocyte count 9,000/mm3
Platelet count 225,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 139 mEq/L
K+ 4.1 mEq/L
Cl− 101 mEq/L
HCO3− 26 mEq/L
Glucose 95 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 78 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 19 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 14 U/L
γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT) 52 U/L (N=5–50 U/L)
Hemoglobin A1C 6.4%
Abdominal ultrasound shows nonpropulsive peristalsis of the small bowel. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?"
A) Chronic inflammatory bowel disease
B) Obesity
C) Ibuprofen
D) History of abdominal surgery
E) Alcohol
answer:

He has <fact5>psoriasis, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain</fact5>. He drinks <fact6>two beers daily</fact6>. Examination shows <fact13>thick, scaly, plaques over both elbows and knees</fact13>. Abdominal examination shows <fact14>three well-healed laparoscopic scars</fact14>. The abdomen is <fact15>distended</fact15> and there are <fact16>requent, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation</fact16>. Digital rectal examination shows an <fact17>empty rectum</fact17>. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit <fact18>44%</fact18>
Leukocyte count <fact19>9,000/mm3</fact19>
Platelet count <fact20>225,000/mm3</fact20>
Serum
Na+ <fact21>139 mEq/L</fact21>
K+ <fact22>4.1 mEq/L</fact22>
Cl− <fact23>101 mEq/L</fact23>
HCO3− <fact24>26 mEq/L</fact24>
Glucose <fact25>95 mg/dL</fact25>
Creatinine <fact26>1.1 mg/dL</fact26>
Alkaline phosphatase <fact27>78 U/L</fact27>
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) <fact28>19 U/L</fact28>
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) <fact29>14 U/L</fact29>
γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT) <fact30>52 U/L</fact30> (N=5–50 U/L)
Hemoglobin A1C <fact31>6.4%</fact31>
Abdominal ultrasound shows <fact32>nonpropulsive peristalsis of the small bowel</fact32>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>increasingly severe abdominal pain, nausea, and bilious vomiting</fact2> and the presence of <fact15>abdominal distension</fact15> and <fact16>high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation</fact16>, along with the abdominal ultrasound findings of <fact32>nonpropulsive peristalsis of the small bowel</fact32>, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is a bowel obstruction. Among the options provided, the patient's <fact4>history of abdominal surgery</fact4> (appendectomy at the age of 39) and the presence of <fact14>three well-healed laparoscopic scars</fact14> suggest that adhesions from previous surgeries could be the cause of the bowel obstruction. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 42-year-old man comes to the physician to establish care. He recently moved to the area and has not been to a primary care physician for over 5 years. He has no history of serious illness, but has intermittent bilateral knee pain for which he takes 650 mg acetaminophen every other day. He is married with three children and is sexually active with his wife. During the past 10 years, he has unsuccessfully tried to lose weight. He has smoked one half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. About 2–3 times per week he has 1–2 glasses of wine with dinner. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 36.3 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On abdominal examination, the liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.6 g/dL
Platelet count 360,000/mm3
Hemoglobin A1c 6.3%
Serum
Ferritin 194 ng/mL
Total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 52 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 92 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 144 U/L
Hepatitis B surface antigen Negative
Hepatitis B core IgM antibody Negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody Positive
Hepatitis C antibody Negative
Antinuclear antibody titers 1:20 (N = < 1:60)
Smooth muscle antibody titers Negative
Anti-LKM1 antibody titers Negative
Transabdominal ultrasonography shows a mildly enlarged, diffusely hyperechoic liver. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these liver abnormalities?"
A) Autoimmune liver damage
B) Congestive hepatopathy
C) Insulin resistance
D) Acetaminophen use
E) Alcohol use
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>42-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician to establish care. He recently moved to the area and has not been to a primary care physician for over <fact2>5 years</fact2>. He has no history of serious illness, but has intermittent bilateral knee pain for which he takes <fact3>650 mg acetaminophen every other day</fact3>. He is <fact7>160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 36.3 kg/m2</fact7>. Vital signs are within normal limits.
