Nebulized <fact13>albuterol and ipratropium treatments</fact13> and intravenous <fact14>methylprednisolone</fact14> are given in the emergency department for a presumed <fact15>asthma exacerbation</fact15>. One hour later, the child is <fact16>limp and lethargic</fact16>. Magnesium sulfate is administered. His <fact17>temperature is 36°C (96.8°F)</fact17>, <fact18>pulse is 150/min</fact18>, <fact19>respirations are 22/min</fact19>, and <fact20>blood pressure is 100/70</fact20>. No <fact21>wheezing is heard on repeat pulmonary examination</fact21>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Given the child's improvement in respiratory symptoms, as indicated by the resolution of <fact10>wheezing</fact10> and decrease in <fact8>respirations</fact8> from 40/min to <fact19>22/min</fact19>, and considering the administration of magnesium sulfate, which can cause muscle weakness and lethargy, the child's current state of being <fact16>limp and lethargic</fact16> is likely a side effect of the treatment rather than a worsening of the asthma exacerbation. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management would be to monitor the child closely and provide supportive care. Among the options provided, the best answer is {D} Provide helium and oxygen mixture, as it can help reduce airway resistance and improve ventilation in patients with asthma, but it is not directly indicated by the information in the question. However, it is the most appropriate choice given the options, as the other choices are more invasive or not directly related to the current management of the child's asthma exacerbation.

question:
An 18-year-old patient is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her annual exam before college starts. Her height and weight are appropriate for her age, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she declined. She is very shy and withdrawn with the physician. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very socially isolated and feels lonely. She is also worried that her daughter is extremely sensitive to criticism, even from family. The daughter is interested in art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars because she says that she is untalented and thinks nobody wants to hang out with her. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter bursts into tears and says, “Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected.” Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior?
A) Schizotypal personality disorder
B) Generalized anxiety disorder
C) Avoidant personality disorder
D) Paranoid personality disorder
E) Dependent personality disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>18-year-old patient</fact1> is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her annual exam before college starts. Her height and weight are appropriate for her age, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she <fact2>declined</fact2>. She is very <fact3>shy and withdrawn</fact3> with the physician. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very <fact4>socially isolated</fact4> and feels <fact5>lonely</fact5>. She is also worried that her daughter is <fact6>extremely sensitive to criticism</fact6>, even from family. The daughter is interested in art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars because she says that she is <fact7>untalented</fact7> and thinks <fact8>nobody wants to hang out with her</fact8>. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter <fact9>bursts into tears</fact9> and says, “<fact10>Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected</fact10>.” Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's behavior and symptoms, the most likely explanation is {C} Avoidant personality disorder. This diagnosis is supported by the patient's <fact2>declining a higher-paying job</fact2>, being <fact3>shy and withdrawn</fact3>, feeling <fact5>lonely</fact5> and <fact4>socially isolated</fact4>, being <fact6>extremely sensitive to criticism</fact6>, and having a negative self-image (<fact7>untalented</fact7> and <fact10>too lame and ugly</fact10>). Additionally, her fear of rejection (<fact8>nobody wants to hang out with her</fact8> and <fact10>I just know I’ll end up getting rejected</fact10>) and her emotional response to her mother's encouragement (<fact9>bursts into tears</fact9>) are also characteristic of avoidant personality disorder.

question:
A 15-year-old female presents to her pediatrician’s office for severe menstrual cramping. The patient underwent menarche at age 11, and her periods were irregular every 2-3 months for two years. After that, her cycles became roughly regular every 28-35 days, but she has had extremely painful cramps and often has to miss school. The cramps are intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen, and there is usually accompanying back pain. The patient has been using heating pads with limited relief. She reports some periods being “really heavy” and requires a superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any bowel or bladder changes. The patient had normal development throughout childhood, is on the soccer team at school, and is not sexually active. Her father has hypertension and her mother has endometriosis and heavy periods. On exam, the patient is 5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2). She is well appearing and has no abdominal tenderness. She has Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair, and external genitalia are normal. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps?
A) Von Willebrand factor antigen assay
B) Pelvic ultrasound
C) MRI of the pelvis
D) NSAIDs
E) Increased exercise
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>15-year-old female</fact1> presents to her pediatrician’s office for <fact2>severe menstrual cramping</fact2>. The patient underwent <fact3>menarche at age 11</fact3>, and her periods were irregular every 2-3 months for two years. After that, her cycles became roughly regular every <fact4>28-35 days</fact4>, but she has had <fact5>extremely painful cramps</fact5> and often has to miss school. The cramps are intermittent and feel like a <fact6>dull ache in the center of her abdomen</fact6>, and there is usually accompanying <fact7>back pain</fact7>. The patient has been using <fact8>heating pads with limited relief</fact8>. She reports some periods being “really heavy” and requires a <fact9>superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle</fact9>, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any <fact10>bowel or bladder changes</fact10>. The patient had normal development throughout childhood, is on the <fact11>soccer team at school</fact11>, and is not sexually active. Her father has <fact12>hypertension</fact12> and her mother has <fact13>endometriosis and heavy periods</fact13>. On exam, the patient is <fact14>5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2)</fact14>. She is well appearing and has no <fact15>abdominal tenderness</fact15>. She has <fact16>Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair</fact16>, and external genitalia are normal. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s <fact2>menstrual cramps</fact2>?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>severe menstrual cramping</fact2> and the absence of any <fact10>bowel or bladder changes</fact10> or <fact15>abdominal tenderness</fact15>, the most likely cause is primary dysmenorrhea. The patient's use of <fact8>heating pads with limited relief</fact8> suggests the need for a more effective treatment option. Given her normal development, regular cycles of <fact4>28-35 days</fact4>, and the absence of any red flags, the best next step would be to try a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) to help alleviate the <fact5>extremely painful cramps</fact5> and <fact7>back pain</fact7>. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 10-year-old African American girl with known sickle cell disease becomes acutely anemic in the setting of underlying infection. Her mother denies any previous history of blood clots in her past, but she says that her mother has also had to be treated for pulmonary embolism in the recent past. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a few episodes of acute pain crisis and a need for splenectomy 3 years ago. The vital signs upon arrival include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 106/74 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min and regular, and respiratory rate 17/min. On physical examination, her pulses are bounding and fingernails are pale, but breath sounds remain clear. Oxygen saturation was initially 91% on room air and electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia. A blood transfusion is initiated. Shortly after the transfusion has begun, the patient experiences fevers, chills, a burning sensation at the intravenous (IV) site, and sudden hypotension. What is the name of this reaction, and what is the best treatment?
A) Minor allergic reaction; administer antihistamines
B) Nonhemolytic febrile reaction; administer antihistamines
C) Minor allergic reaction; discontinue transfusion
D) Hemolytic transfusion reaction; administer antihistamines
E) Hemolytic transfusion reaction; discontinue transfusion
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>10-year-old African American girl</fact1> with known <fact2>sickle cell disease</fact2> becomes acutely anemic in the setting of underlying infection. Her mother denies any previous history of <fact3>blood clots</fact3> in her past, but she says that her mother has also had to be treated for <fact4>pulmonary embolism</fact4> in the recent past. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a few episodes of <fact5>acute pain crisis</fact5> and a need for <fact6>splenectomy</fact6> 3 years ago. The vital signs upon arrival include: temperature <fact7>36.7°C (98.0°F)</fact7>, blood pressure <fact8>106/74 mm Hg</fact8>, heart rate <fact9>111/min</fact9> and regular, and respiratory rate <fact10>17/min</fact10>. On physical examination, her pulses are bounding and fingernails are pale, but breath sounds remain clear. Oxygen saturation was initially <fact11>91% on room air</fact11> and electrocardiogram (ECG) shows <fact12>sinus tachycardia</fact12>. A blood transfusion is initiated. Shortly after the transfusion has begun, the patient experiences <fact13>fevers</fact13>, <fact14>chills</fact14>, a <fact15>burning sensation at the intravenous (IV) site</fact15>, and <fact16>sudden hypotension</fact16>. What is the name of this reaction, and what is the best treatment?

Answer: Given the patient's symptoms of <fact13>fevers</fact13>, <fact14>chills</fact14>, <fact15>burning sensation at the intravenous (IV) site</fact15>, and <fact16>sudden hypotension</fact16> shortly after the blood transfusion began, the reaction is most likely a hemolytic transfusion reaction. This is a severe and potentially life-threatening reaction that requires immediate attention. The best course of action is to discontinue the transfusion to prevent further hemolysis and to administer supportive care to manage symptoms. Therefore, the correct answer is {E} Hemolytic transfusion reaction; discontinue transfusion.

question:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks. During this time he has felt like his eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings and his urine has been frothy. He has hypertension and rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen. He does not smoke. He has a history of chronic alcohol abuse. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites. He has swan-neck deformities and nodules of multiple fingers and swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.2 mg/dl
Prothrombin time 12 seconds
Serum
Albumin 2.8 g/dl
Total bilirubin 1.0 mg/dl
Alkaline phosphatase 120 U/L
AST 20 U/L
ALT 19 U/L
Urea 18 mg/dl
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
Urine
Protein 3+
WBCs 5–10/hpf
RBCs negative
Bacteria negative
Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?"
A) Adverse effect of ibuprofen
B) Decreased cardiac ejection fraction
C) Renal deposition of AL amyloid
D) Increased serum amyloid A production
E) Renal deposition of anti-dsDNA immune complexes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>66-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks</fact2>. During this time he has felt like his <fact3>eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings</fact3> and his <fact4>urine has been frothy</fact4>. He has <fact5>hypertension</fact5> and <fact6>rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis</fact6>. Current medications include <fact7>amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen</fact7>. He does not smoke. He has a <fact8>history of chronic alcohol abuse</fact8>. His <fact9>temperature is 36.7°C (98°F)</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 80/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg</fact11>. Physical examination shows <fact12>pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites</fact12>. He has <fact13>swan-neck deformities and nodules of multiple fingers</fact13> and <fact14>swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints</fact14>. Laboratory studies show:
<fact15>Hemoglobin 8.2 mg/dl</fact15>
<fact16>Prothrombin time 12 seconds</fact16>
Serum
<fact17>Albumin 2.8 g/dl</fact17>
<fact18>Total bilirubin 1.0 mg/dl</fact18>
<fact19>Alkaline phosphatase 120 U/L</fact19>
<fact20>AST 20 U/L</fact20>
<fact21>ALT 19 U/L</fact21>
<fact22>Urea 18 mg/dl</fact22>
<fact23>Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl</fact23>
Urine
<fact24>Protein 3+</fact24>
<fact25>WBCs 5–10/hpf</fact25>
<fact26>RBCs negative</fact26>
<fact27>Bacteria negative</fact27>
Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows <fact28>no abnormalities</fact28>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

Answer: 
Analyzing the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, the presence of <fact2>fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks</fact2>, <fact3>eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings</fact3>, and <fact4>urine has been frothy</fact4> suggests a possible nephrotic syndrome. The laboratory findings of <fact17>low albumin levels (2.8 g/dl)</fact17> and <fact24>proteinuria (3+)</fact24> further support this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's <fact6>rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis</fact6> and <fact8>history of chronic alcohol abuse</fact8> increase the risk for secondary amyloidosis. The deposition of amyloid proteins in the kidneys can lead to nephrotic syndrome. Among the provided options, <factC>Renal deposition of AL amyloid</factC> is the most likely cause of this patient's findings.

question:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent diarrhea and fatigue for 1 month. She has had up to 12 watery stools per day. Sometimes she awakens at night because she has to defecate. She has abdominal bloating and cramps. She has had a 2-kg weight loss in the past month. She returned from a trip to Costa Rica 7 weeks ago. She has a history of bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa. She works as a nurse. She does not smoke and drinks 1–2 beers on the weekend. Current medications include fish oil, a multivitamin, and a salbutamol inhaler. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Abdominal and rectal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 46%
Leukocyte Count 6,500/mm3
Platelet Count 220,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
K+ 3.2 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 33 mEq/L
Mg2+ 3.3 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Abdominal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy shows dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots. Biopsies of colonic mucosa are obtained and sent for pathological evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?"
A) Celiac disease
B) Carcinoid tumor
C) VIPoma
D) Irritable bowel syndrome
E) Medication abuse
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>persistent diarrhea and fatigue for 1 month</fact2>. She has had up to <fact3>12 watery stools per day</fact3>. Sometimes she awakens at night because she has to defecate. She has <fact4>abdominal bloating and cramps</fact4>. She has had a <fact5>2-kg weight loss in the past month</fact5>. She returned from a trip to <fact6>Costa Rica 7 weeks ago</fact6>. She has a history of <fact7>bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa</fact7>. She works as a <fact8>nurse</fact8>. She does not smoke and drinks <fact9>1–2 beers on the weekend</fact9>. Current medications include <fact10>fish oil, a multivitamin, and a salbutamol inhaler</fact10>. Her temperature is <fact11>36.8°C (98.2°F)</fact11>, pulse is <fact12>65/min</fact12>, and blood pressure is <fact13>100/75 mm Hg</fact13>. Examination shows <fact14>dry mucous membranes</fact14>. Abdominal and rectal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
<fact15>Hematocrit 46%</fact15>
<fact16>Leukocyte Count 6,500/mm3</fact16>
<fact17>Platelet Count 220,000/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Serum Na+ 136 mEq/L</fact18>
<fact19>K+ 3.2 mEq/L</fact19>
<fact20>Cl- 102 mEq/L</fact20>
<fact21>HCO3- 33 mEq/L</fact21>
<fact22>Mg2+ 3.3 mEq/L</fact22>
<fact23>Urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL</fact23>
<fact24>Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL</fact24>
Abdominal ultrasound shows <fact25>no abnormalities</fact25>. Colonoscopy shows <fact26>dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots</fact26>. Biopsies of colonic mucosa are obtained and sent for pathological evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>persistent diarrhea and fatigue for 1 month</fact2>, with <fact3>12 watery stools per day</fact3>, <fact4>abdominal bloating and cramps</fact4>, and a <fact5>2-kg weight loss in the past month</fact5>, the most likely underlying cause is related to a gastrointestinal disorder. The patient's recent travel to <fact6>Costa Rica 7 weeks ago</fact6> could suggest an infectious cause, but the absence of fever (<fact11>36.8°C or 98.2°F</fact11>) and normal laboratory values (<fact15>-<fact24>) make this less likely. The patient's history of <fact7>bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa</fact7> is also important, but the symptoms do not directly correlate with these conditions. The key finding is the colonoscopy result showing <fact26>dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots</fact26>, which is suggestive of a specific condition. Among the options provided, the description is most consistent with a <fact26>carcinoid tumor</fact26> (choice B), which can cause diarrhea and abdominal cramping due to the secretion of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the complaint of pain in his right toe for the past hour. The pain is so severe that it woke him up. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and binge drinks alcohol after work and on the weekends. He underwent an appendectomy when he was 14 years old. He is a long-distance truck driver. Neither of his parents had any significant medical history. His temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and BMI is 25 kg/m2. On examination, his right first metatarsophalangeal joint is very tender, swollen, warm, and red in color. Range of motion cannot be assessed due to extreme tenderness.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocytes 16,000/mm3
Platelets 150,000/mm3
ESR 50 mm/hr
Synovial fluid is aspirated from the joint. The findings are:
Appearance Cloudy, dense yellow
WBC 30,000 cells/µL
Culture Negative
Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition?
A) Organic acids competing with urate for tubular secretion
B) Increased renal reabsorption of urate
C) Lysis of large numbers of cells
D) Deficiency of HGPRT
E) High-purine diet
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>55-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department with the complaint of <fact2>pain in his right toe</fact2> for the past hour. The pain is so severe that it woke him up. The patient has <fact3>smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years</fact3> and <fact4>binge drinks alcohol after work and on the weekends</fact4>. He underwent an appendectomy when he was 14 years old. He is a <fact5>long-distance truck driver</fact5>. Neither of his parents had any significant medical history. His temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and BMI is 25 kg/m2. On examination, his right first metatarsophalangeal joint is very tender, swollen, warm, and red in color. Range of motion cannot be assessed due to extreme tenderness.

Laboratory test
Complete blood count:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocytes 16,000/mm3
Platelets 150,000/mm3
ESR 50 mm/hr
Synovial fluid is aspirated from the joint. The findings are:
Appearance Cloudy, dense yellow
WBC 30,000 cells/µL
Culture Negative
Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition?

A) Organic acids competing with urate for tubular secretion
B) Increased renal reabsorption of urate
C) Lysis of large numbers of cells
D) Deficiency of HGPRT
E) High-purine diet

Answer: 
The patient's condition, characterized by <fact2>pain in his right toe</fact2>, a tender and swollen metatarsophalangeal joint, and the presence of <fact6>needle-shaped birefringent crystals in the joint aspirate</fact6>, is indicative of gout. Gout is often associated with hyperuricemia, which can result from various factors including diet, lifestyle, and underlying medical conditions. Among the provided options, a <fact4>high-purine diet</fact4> is a known risk factor for developing gout, as it can lead to increased uric acid production. Additionally, the patient's history of <fact3>smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years</fact3> and <fact4>binge drinking alcohol</fact4> may also contribute to his condition, as these habits can increase uric acid levels. Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition is {E}.

question:
A 35-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist for an initial consultation. She reports that for the past 3 years, she has experienced several periods of depressed mood. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and seem to resolve after 4-6 weeks. During these episodes, she experiences a depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite, but she at times is able to enjoy spending time with her children and husband but other times she is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, she also reports experiencing occasional episodes of elevated mood over the past ten years. During these episodes, she is very productive at her work as a lawyer and requires less sleep than usual. Her past medical history is notable for obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis. She is on insulin and takes methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is quiet with a flattened affect, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Bipolar I disorder
B) Bipolar II disorder
C) Cyclothymic disorder
D) Persistent depressive disorder
E) Schizoaffective disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> presents to a psychiatrist for an initial consultation. She reports that for the past <fact2>3 years</fact2>, she has experienced several periods of <fact3>depressed mood</fact3>. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and seem to resolve after <fact4>4-6 weeks</fact4>. During these episodes, she experiences a <fact3>depressed mood</fact3>, <fact5>sleep disturbances</fact5>, and a <fact6>poor appetite</fact6>, but she at times is able to enjoy spending time with her children and husband but other times she is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, she also reports experiencing occasional episodes of <fact7>elevated mood</fact7> over the past <fact8>ten years</fact8>. During these episodes, she is very productive at her work as a lawyer and requires <fact9>less sleep than usual</fact9>. Her past medical history is notable for <fact10>obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis</fact10>. She is on insulin and takes methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is quiet with a <fact11>flattened affect</fact11>, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly.

Answer: 

The patient's symptoms of <fact3>depressed mood</fact3>, <fact5>sleep disturbances</fact5>, and <fact6>poor appetite</fact6> that resolve after <fact4>4-6 weeks</fact4> suggest a mood disorder. Additionally, the patient reports experiencing episodes of <fact7>elevated mood</fact7> over the past <fact8>ten years</fact8>, during which she is very productive and requires <fact9>less sleep than usual</fact9>. However, the patient's symptoms do not meet the criteria for a manic episode, as she does not exhibit any psychotic symptoms or require hospitalization. The patient's <fact11>flattened affect</fact11> and occasional inability to enjoy time with her children and husband also suggest a mood disorder. Given the patient's symptoms of both depressed and elevated mood, the most likely diagnosis is <fact12>Bipolar II disorder</fact12>, which is characterized by at least one major depressive episode and at least one hypomanic episode. Therefore, the answer is B.

question:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had insomnia and daytime sleepiness during this period. Her last bowel movement was 3 days ago. One month ago, she underwent a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement. She has alcoholic liver cirrhosis. Current medications include spironolactone and furosemide. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit 2 months ago. She is oriented to place and person. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There are several telangiectasias over the chest and back. Palmar erythema is present. The abdomen is mildly distended and nontender. Shifting dullness is present. There is a flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. She completes the number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Reversal of TIPS
B) Paracentesis
C) Administer IV ceftriaxone
D) Administer lactulose
E) Administer vitamin B1
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of <fact2>increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability</fact2> for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had <fact3>insomnia and daytime sleepiness</fact3> during this period. Her last bowel movement was <fact4>3 days ago</fact4>. One month ago, she underwent a <fact5>transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement</fact5>. She has <fact6>alcoholic liver cirrhosis</fact6>. Current medications include <fact7>spironolactone and furosemide</fact7>. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit <fact8>2 months ago</fact8>. She is oriented to place and person. Her temperature is <fact9>37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact9>, pulse is <fact10>88/min</fact10>, and blood pressure is <fact11>102/64 mm Hg</fact11>. Examination shows <fact12>scleral icterus and jaundice</fact12>. There are several <fact13>telangiectasias over the chest and back</fact13>. <fact14>Palmar erythema is present</fact14>. The abdomen is mildly distended and nontender. <fact15>Shifting dullness is present</fact15>. There is a <fact16>flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed</fact16>. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. She completes the number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation of <fact2>increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability</fact2> along with <fact3>insomnia and daytime sleepiness</fact3>, and considering her history of <fact6>alcoholic liver cirrhosis</fact6> and recent <fact5>transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement</fact5>, it is likely that she is experiencing hepatic encephalopathy. The presence of <fact12>scleral icterus and jaundice</fact12>, <fact13>telangiectasias over the chest and back</fact13>, <fact14>palmar erythema</fact14>, and <fact15>shifting dullness</fact15> further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the <fact16>flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed</fact16> is a classic sign of hepatic encephalopathy. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer lactulose, which is a standard treatment for hepatic encephalopathy. Lactulose helps to reduce ammonia production in the gut, thereby alleviating symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of low back pain and weakness for the past 4 weeks. He says that the pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality. He has had a cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 months. He has had 3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had constipation and difficulty urinating for the past 2 weeks. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
A) Radiation therapy
B) Intravenous dexamethasone therapy
C) Intravenous acyclovir therapy
D) Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin therapy
E) Oral ibuprofen therapy
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>76-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the physician by his wife because of <fact2>low back pain and weakness</fact2> for the past <fact3>4 weeks</fact3>. He says that the <fact4>pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality</fact4>. He has had a <fact5>cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum</fact5> for the past <fact6>2 months</fact6>. He has had <fact7>3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss</fact7> in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had <fact8>constipation and difficulty urinating</fact8> for the past <fact9>2 weeks</fact9>. He has <fact10>hypertension treated with enalapril</fact10>. He has <fact11>smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 75/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg</fact14>. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows <fact15>3/5 strength of the lower extremities</fact15>. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows <fact16>decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome</fact16>. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An <fact17>x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs</fact17>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>low back pain and weakness</fact2>, <fact4>pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality</fact4>, <fact5>cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum</fact5>, and <fact7>weight loss</fact7>, along with the <fact17>x-ray of the chest showing multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs</fact17>, it is likely that the patient has metastatic cancer, possibly lung cancer, given his <fact11>long history of smoking</fact11>. The presence of <fact8>constipation and difficulty urinating</fact8>, <fact15>3/5 strength of the lower extremities</fact15>, and <fact16>decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome</fact16> suggests spinal cord compression. The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient is to start <fact18>intravenous dexamethasone therapy</fact18> to reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms of spinal cord compression. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 36-year-old man presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a 15-pack-year history of smoking who tried quitting several times. He tried different nicotine replacement products, none of which helped him. The patient has gastrointestinal reflux disease and takes omeprazole. The medical history is significant for a head trauma after which he had two seizure episodes. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any antiepileptic medication. He heard from his friend about an antidepressant that efficiently helps with smoking cessation. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct?
A) Omeprazole interferes with bupropion metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to omeprazole consumption.
B) Bupropion is only effective when used together with nicotine replacement products.
C) Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.
D) The physician may prescribe bupropion for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed.
E) This patient has no contraindications for bupropion and may safely use it.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a <fact2>15-pack-year history of smoking</fact2> who tried quitting several times. He tried different <fact3>nicotine replacement products</fact3>, none of which helped him. The patient has <fact4>gastrointestinal reflux disease</fact4> and takes <fact5>omeprazole</fact5>. The medical history is significant for a <fact6>head trauma</fact6> after which he had <fact7>two seizure episodes</fact7>. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any <fact8>antiepileptic medication</fact8>. He heard from his friend about an <fact9>antidepressant</fact9> that efficiently helps with smoking cessation. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct?

A) <fact10>Omeprazole</fact10> interferes with <fact11>bupropion</fact11> metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to <fact10>omeprazole</fact10> consumption.
B) <fact11>Bupropion</fact11> is only effective when used together with <fact3>nicotine replacement products</fact3>.
C) <fact11>Bupropion</fact11> lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of <fact7>seizure disorder</fact7>.
D) The physician may prescribe <fact11>bupropion</fact11> for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed.
E) This patient has no contraindications for <fact11>bupropion</fact11> and may safely use it.

Answer: C) <fact11>Bupropion</fact11> lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of <fact7>seizure disorder</fact7>.

question:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day. The cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm. He has metastatic colon cancer and has received three cycles of chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin; his last chemotherapy session was 2.5 months ago. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has been treated with antibiotics and prednisolone for acute exacerbations three times in the past year. His medications include a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler and a tiotropium bromide inhaler. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. His temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 88/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An x-ray of the chest shows a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung. Two sets of blood cultures are obtained. Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows gram-negative rods. Two large bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
A) Ceftriaxone and azithromycin
B) Ertapenem
C) Colistin
D) Cefepime and levofloxacin
E) Clarithromycin and amoxicillin-clavulanate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of a <fact2>cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day</fact2>. The <fact3>cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm</fact3>. He has <fact4>metastatic colon cancer</fact4> and has received three cycles of chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin; his last chemotherapy session was 2.5 months ago. He has <fact5>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease</fact5> and has been treated with antibiotics and prednisolone for acute exacerbations three times in the past year. His medications include a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler and a tiotropium bromide inhaler. He has <fact6>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years</fact6>. His <fact7>temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 112/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 32/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 88/69 mm Hg</fact10>. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an <fact11>oxygen saturation of 88%</fact11>. Pulmonary examination shows <fact12>diffuse crackles and rhonchi</fact12>. An x-ray of the chest shows a <fact13>left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung</fact13>. Two sets of blood cultures are obtained. Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows <fact14>gram-negative rods</fact14>. Two large bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day</fact2>, productive of <fact3>green phlegm</fact3>, and the presence of <fact14>gram-negative rods</fact14> on endotracheal aspirate Gram stain, the patient likely has a bacterial pneumonia. Given the patient's history of <fact4>metastatic colon cancer</fact4> and <fact5>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease</fact5>, as well as his recent chemotherapy and smoking history (<fact6>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years</fact6>), he is at increased risk for severe infection and may require broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient's <fact7>temperature of 39.1°C (103.1°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse of 112/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations of 32/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure of 88/69 mm Hg</fact10> indicate sepsis, which necessitates prompt and effective antibiotic therapy. The combination of <fact14>gram-negative rods</fact14> and the patient's severe clinical presentation suggests the need for broad-spectrum coverage. Among the options provided, choice D, Cefepime and levofloxacin, offers broad-spectrum coverage against gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a common pathogen in severe pneumonia, especially in patients with underlying lung disease like <fact5>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease</fact5>. This combination also covers a wide range of other potential pathogens. Therefore, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is {D}.

question:
A 14-year-old teenager presents to his pediatrician complaining of frequent headaches and excessive fatigue during soccer practice. His mother notes that he seems to have gained a lot of weight despite the fact that he eats a healthy, well-balanced diet. His teachers have also become concerned because he leaves class to use the restroom frequently throughout the day. He has no medical problems and family history is insignificant. A physical exam is significant for a short, overweight child with nonpitting edema and decreased reflexes. His systolic blood pressure drops by 20 mm Hg when he stands. Fundoscopic exam is significant for papilledema and visual field exam is significant for bitemporal hemianopsia. Laboratory findings include:
BUN 22 mg/dL N: 7–20 mg/dL
pCO2 32 mm Hg N: 35–45 mm Hg
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL N: 0.8–1.4 mg/dL
Glucose 50 mg/dL N: 64–128 mg/dL
Serum chloride 95 mmol/L N: 101–111 mmol/L
Serum potassium 3.3 mEq/L N: 3.7–5.2 mEq/L
Serum sodium 120 mEq/L N: 136–144 mEq/L
Bicarbonate (HCO3) 15 mmol/L N: 18–22 mmol/L
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 0.1 mIU/L N: 0.5–5 mIU/L
Free T4 6 pmol/L N: 10–20 pmol/L
What is the necessary treatment?
A) Chemotherapy, surgical resection and radiation
B) Chemotherapy and radiation
C) Chemotherapy
D) Surgical resection
E) Hormone replacement therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old teenager</fact1> presents to his pediatrician complaining of <fact2> frequent headaches and excessive fatigue during soccer practice</fact2>. His mother notes that he seems to have gained a lot of weight despite the fact that he eats a healthy, well-balanced diet. His teachers have also become concerned because he leaves class to use the restroom frequently throughout the day. He has no medical problems and family history is insignificant. A physical exam is significant for a <fact3>short, overweight child with nonpitting edema and decreased reflexes</fact3>. His systolic blood pressure drops by 20 mm Hg when he stands. <fact5>BUN 22 mg/dL N: 7–20 mg/dL</fact5>
<fact6>pCO2 32 mm Hg N: 35–45 mm Hg</fact6>
<fact7>Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL N: 0.8–1.4 mg/dL</fact7>
<fact8>Glucose 50 mg/dL N: 64–128 mg/dL</fact8>
<fact9>Serum chloride 95 mmol/L N: 101–111 mmol/L</fact9>
<fact10>Serum potassium 3.3 mEq/L N: 3.7–5.2 mEq/L</fact10>
<fact11>Serum sodium 120 mEq/L N: 136–144 mEq/L</fact11>
<fact12>Bicarbonate (HCO3) 15 mmol/L N: 18–22 mmol/L</fact12>
<fact13>Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 0.1 mIU/L N: 0.5–5 mIU/L</fact13>
<fact14>Free T4 6 pmol/L N: 10–20 pmol/L</fact14>
What is the necessary treatment?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2> frequent headaches and excessive fatigue during soccer practice</fact2>, along with physical examination findings of <fact3>a short, overweight child with nonpitting edema and decreased reflexes</fact3>, and laboratory results showing <fact8>low glucose</fact8>, <fact11>low serum sodium</fact11>, and <fact13>low TSH</fact13> with <fact14>low Free T4</fact14>, it is evident that the patient is experiencing hypothyroidism. Additionally, the presence of <fact4>papilledema and visual field exam is significant for bitemporal hemianopsia</fact4> suggests that there may be a pituitary tumor causing secondary hypothyroidism. However, the primary issue that needs to be addressed is the hypothyroidism. Therefore, the necessary treatment is {E} hormone replacement therapy.

question:
A 74-year-old man undergoes an open cholecystectomy. Surgery is performed under general anesthesia for which the patient is intubated with an endotracheal tube. Directly following the procedure, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is extubated as soon as he showed signs of alertness. Five minutes later, he becomes unresponsive. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He underwent stenting of the right coronary artery 10 years ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 weeks ago for surgery. He drinks one to two beers daily. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 73%. He is put on a non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%. Three minutes later, he is still unresponsive. His arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.32
PCO2 33 mm Hg
PO2 73 mm Hg
HCO3 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 73%
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
A) Perform tracheostomy
B) Continue using the non-rebreather mask
C) Reintubate
D) Close observation only
E) Start BiPAP
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>74-year-old man</fact1> undergoes an <fact2>open cholecystectomy</fact2>. Surgery is performed under <fact3>general anesthesia</fact3> for which the patient is <fact4>intubated with an endotracheal tube</fact4>. Directly following the procedure, his <fact5>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 80/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg</fact7>. He is <fact8>extubated as soon as he showed signs of alertness</fact8>. Five minutes later, he becomes <fact9>unresponsive</fact9>. He has <fact10>type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypertension</fact10>. He underwent <fact11>stenting of the right coronary artery 10 years ago</fact11>. He <fact12>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years</fact12> but quit 2 weeks ago for surgery. He drinks <fact13>one to two beers daily</fact13>. His current medications include <fact14>metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin</fact14>. His <fact15>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact15>, <fact16>pulse is 102/min</fact16>, <fact17>respirations are 20/min</fact17>, and <fact18>blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg</fact18>. <fact19>Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 73%</fact19>. He is put on a <fact20>non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%</fact20>. Three minutes later, he is still <fact21>unresponsive</fact21>. His <fact22>arterial blood gas analysis</fact22> shows:
pH 7.32
PCO2 33 mm Hg
PO2 73 mm Hg
HCO3 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 73%
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
The patient's situation is critical, with an <fact19>oxygen saturation of 73%</fact19> despite being on a <fact20>non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%</fact20> for three minutes. His <fact22>arterial blood gas analysis</fact22> shows severe hypoxemia with a PO2 of 73 mm Hg. Given his <fact9>unresponsiveness</fact9> and the failure of supplemental oxygen to improve his oxygenation, the best next step is to secure his airway. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}, as <fact4>reintubation</fact4> is necessary to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

question:
A 36-year-old man presents to a physician after having a transient loss of consciousness while resting after dinner the previous night. His symptoms only lasted for a few seconds and resolved spontaneously. This is the third time he experienced such an episode. He says that he recently started having nightmares. His father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 45 years without a history of hypertension or any chronic cardiac disorder. A complete physical examination was normal. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevations in V1, V2, and V3, and the presence of incomplete right bundle branch block (RBBB). After a complete diagnostic evaluation, Brugada syndrome was diagnosed. He has prescribed a class I anti-arrhythmic drug, which is a sodium channel blocker that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular muscle fibers. The drug also blocks potassium channels and prolongs action potential duration, but it does not shorten phase 3 repolarization. The drug also has mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity. If taken in high doses, which of the following are the most likely side effects of the drug?
A) Headache and tinnitus
B) Pulmonary fibrosis and corneal deposits
C) Dyslipidemia and hypoglycemia unawareness
D) Pedal edema and flushing
E) Hypothyroidism and phototoxicity
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> presents to a physician after having a transient loss of consciousness while resting after dinner the previous night. His symptoms only lasted for a few seconds and resolved spontaneously. This is the third time he experienced such an episode. He says that he recently started having nightmares. His father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 45 years without a history of hypertension or any chronic cardiac disorder. A complete physical examination was normal. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed <fact2>ST-segment elevations in V1, V2, and V3, and the presence of incomplete right bundle branch block (RBBB)</fact2>. After a complete diagnostic evaluation, <fact3>Brugada syndrome</fact3> was diagnosed. He has prescribed a <fact4>class I anti-arrhythmic drug, which is a sodium channel blocker that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular muscle fibers</fact4>. The drug also <fact5>blocks potassium channels and prolongs action potential duration, but it does not shorten phase 3 repolarization</fact5>. The drug also has <fact6>mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity</fact6>. If taken in high doses, which of the following are the most likely side effects of the drug?

Answer: Considering the <fact4>class I anti-arrhythmic drug</fact4> has <fact6>mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity</fact6>, if taken in high doses, the most likely side effects would be related to these properties. The anticholinergic effects can cause dry mouth, constipation, and urinary retention, but among the options provided, the closest match related to anticholinergic effects is not explicitly listed. However, the alpha-blocking activity can lead to vasodilation, which may cause side effects such as orthostatic hypotension, dizziness, and reflex tachycardia. Among the options, the closest match related to alpha-blocking activity is not explicitly listed either. However, considering the options provided, the most likely side effects related to the overall pharmacological profile of the drug, including its effects on potassium channels and sodium channels, would be more systemic. Therefore, the best match among the options provided, considering the general pharmacological profile of a drug with such properties, would be option {D}, which mentions pedal edema and flushing, both of which could be related to the drug's effects on vascular tone and fluid balance.

question:
A 41-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with abdominal pain. He says that the pain “comes and goes” throughout the day and usually lasts 20-30 minutes per episode. He can point to the spot 1-2 inches above the umbilicus where he feels the pain. He denies any feeling of regurgitation or nighttime cough but endorses nausea. He reports that he used to eat three large meals per day but has found that eating more frequently improves his pain. He tried a couple pills of ibuprofen with food over the past couple days and thinks it helped. He has gained four pounds since his past appointment three months ago. The patient denies any diarrhea or change in his stools. He has no past medical history. He drinks 5-6 beers on the weekend and has a 20 pack-year smoking history. He denies any family history of cancer. On physical exam, he is tender to palpation above the umbilicus. Bowel sounds are present. A stool guaiac test is positive. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy to diagnose his condition.

Which of the following is most likely to be found on histology?
A) Mucosal defect in the stomach
B) Urease-producing organism in the small intestine
C) PAS-positive material in the small intestine
D) Noncaseating granulomas in the small intestine
E) Crypt abscesses in the large intestine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>41-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider with <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. He says that the <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2> “comes and goes” throughout the day and usually lasts <fact3>20-30 minutes per episode</fact3>. He can point to the spot <fact4>1-2 inches above the umbilicus</fact4> where he feels the <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. He denies any feeling of <fact5>regurgitation or nighttime cough</fact5> but endorses <fact6>nausea</fact6>. He reports that he used to eat three large meals per day but has found that eating more frequently improves his <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. He tried a couple pills of <fact7>ibuprofen with food</fact7> over the past couple days and thinks it helped. He has gained <fact8>four pounds</fact8> since his past appointment three months ago. The patient denies any <fact9>diarrhea or change in his stools</fact9>. He has no past medical history. He drinks <fact10>5-6 beers on the weekend</fact10> and has a <fact11>20 pack-year smoking history</fact11>. He denies any family history of cancer. On physical exam, he is <fact12>tender to palpation above the umbilicus</fact12>. Bowel sounds are present. A <fact13>stool guaiac test is positive</fact13>. The patient undergoes <fact14>endoscopy with biopsy</fact14> to diagnose his condition.

Which of the following is most likely to be found on histology?
A) Mucosal defect in the stomach
B) Urease-producing organism in the small intestine
C) PAS-positive material in the small intestine
D) Noncaseating granulomas in the small intestine
E) Crypt abscesses in the large intestine

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2> that is improved by eating more frequently and taking <fact7>ibuprofen with food</fact7>, along with the positive <fact13>stool guaiac test</fact13> and <fact12>tenderness to palpation above the umbilicus</fact12>, the most likely diagnosis is a peptic ulcer disease. On histology, a mucosal defect in the stomach or duodenum would be expected. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of pallor and increasing lethargy for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a 6-week roadtrip in Mexico because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him oral rehydration solution. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 45,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec
Serum
Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 2.5 mg/dL
Direct 0.1 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L
A blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"
A) Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
B) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
C) Hemolytic uremic syndrome
D) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
E) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>2-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for evaluation of <fact2>pallor and increasing lethargy</fact2> for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced <fact3>abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea</fact3> that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a 6-week roadtrip in <fact4>Mexico</fact4> because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him oral rehydration solution. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His <fact5>temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 130/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 35/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg</fact8>. Examination shows <fact9>scleral icterus</fact9>. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
<fact10>Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL</fact10>
<fact11>Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3</fact11>
<fact12>Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3</fact12>
<fact13>Platelet count 45,000/mm3</fact13>
<fact14>Prothrombin time 12 sec</fact14>
<fact15>Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec</fact15>
Serum
<fact16>Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL</fact16>
<fact17>Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL</fact17>
Bilirubin
<fact18>Total 2.5 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Direct 0.1 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L</fact20>
A blood smear shows <fact21>schistocytes</fact21>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: Considering the <fact1>2-year-old boy's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>pallor and increasing lethargy</fact2> following an episode of <fact3>abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea</fact3>, particularly after returning from <fact4>Mexico</fact4>, suggests an infection-related complication. The laboratory findings, including a low <fact10>hemoglobin level</fact10>, elevated <fact12>leukocyte count</fact12>, low <fact13>platelet count</fact13>, and the presence of <fact21>schistocytes</fact21> on the blood smear, point towards a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Additionally, the elevated <fact16>urea nitrogen</fact16> and <fact17>creatinine levels</fact17> indicate renal impairment. These findings are consistent with Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), a condition characterized by the triad of hemolytic anemia, acute kidney injury, and thrombocytopenia. HUS is often preceded by a diarrheal illness, typically caused by Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli, which is consistent with the patient's recent travel to <fact4>Mexico</fact4> and initial symptoms. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {C}.

question:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness. He has no cough. He was treated for a neck abscess 6 months ago. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks two to three beers daily. He has been using intravenous cocaine and heroin for 6 years. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows track marks on both cubital fossae. There are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the lower left sternal border. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,300/mm3
Platelet count 278,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 96 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL
AST 18 U/L
ALT 22 U/L
Transthoracic echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Two sets of blood cultures are collected. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Transesophageal echocardiography
B) Intravenous vancomycin therapy
C) X-ray of the chest
D) CT pulmonary angiogram
E) Intravenous ciprofloxacin therapy
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A <fact1>28-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of a <fact2>3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness</fact2>. He has no <fact3>cough</fact3>. He was treated for a <fact4>neck abscess 6 months ago</fact4>. He takes no medications. He has <fact5>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years</fact5> and <fact6>drinks two to three beers daily</fact6>. He has been <fact7>using intravenous cocaine and heroin for 6 years</fact7>. He appears ill. His <fact8>temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 112/min</fact9>, <fact10>respirations are 20/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact11>. Examination shows <fact12>track marks on both cubital fossae</fact12>. There are <fact13>retinal hemorrhages with pale centers</fact13>. The <fact14>lungs are clear to auscultation</fact14>. A <fact15>grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur</fact15> is heard best at the <fact16>lower left sternal border</fact16>. Laboratory studies show:
<fact17>Hemoglobin 13.3 g/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Leukocyte count 14,300/mm3</fact18>
<fact19>Platelet count 278,000/mm3</fact19>
Serum
<fact20>Glucose 96 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21> Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL</fact22>
<fact23>AST 18 U/L</fact23>
<fact24>ALT 22 U/L</fact24>
<fact25>Transthoracic echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation</fact25>. Two sets of blood cultures are collected. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>fever, chills, and generalized weakness</fact2>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact12>track marks on both cubital fossae</fact12> and <fact15>a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur</fact15>, and the transthoracic echocardiography results showing <fact25>multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation</fact25>, the most likely diagnosis is infective endocarditis. Given the patient's history of <fact7>intravenous cocaine and heroin use</fact7>, there is a high risk of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to initiate empiric antibiotic therapy with <fact26>intravenous vancomycin</fact26>, which is effective against MRSA. The answer is {B}.

question:
Two hours after admission to the hospital for dialysis, a 63-year-old woman has severe pain in her lower back. The pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity and radiates down the legs. She underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 4 years ago. She has hypertension, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and major depressive disorder. She lives with her daughter and reports frequent fights with her at home. Her current medications include sertraline, insulin, enalapril, sodium bicarbonate, and sevelamer. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/94 mm Hg. There is severe tenderness on palpation over the L2 vertebra; range of motion is limited. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8,700/mm3
Platelet count 130,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 5.1 mEq/L
Calcium 8.2 mg/dL
Urea nitrogen 33 mg/dL
Glucose 190 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.8 mg/dL
An x-ray of the spine shows a wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?"
A) Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
B) Secondary hyperparathyroidism
C) Elder abuse
D) Pseudohypoparathyroidism
E) Primary hyperparathyroidism
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>63-year-old woman</fact1> is admitted to the hospital for dialysis and experiences <fact2>severe pain in her lower back</fact2> two hours later. The pain is <fact3>8 out of 10 in intensity and radiates down the legs</fact3>. She has a history of <fact4>hypertension, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and major depressive disorder</fact4>. Her current medications include <fact5>sertraline, insulin, enalapril, sodium bicarbonate, and sevelamer</fact5>. She appears uncomfortable with a <fact6>temperature of 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse of 102/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations of 15/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure of 132/94 mm Hg</fact9>. There is <fact10>severe tenderness on palpation over the L2 vertebra</fact10> and <fact11>limited range of motion</fact11>. Laboratory studies show <fact12>hyperkalemia (K+ 5.1 mEq/L)</fact12>, <fact13>hyperphosphatemia (not explicitly stated but can be inferred from elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine levels)</fact13>, and <fact14>elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine levels (33 mg/dL and 3.8 mg/dL, respectively)</fact14>. An x-ray of the spine shows a <fact15>wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra</fact15>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>63-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>severe pain in her lower back</fact2> and a history of <fact4>chronic kidney disease</fact4>, which is a significant risk factor for secondary hyperparathyroidism due to the inability of the kidneys to activate vitamin D and excrete phosphate. The laboratory findings of <fact12>hyperkalemia</fact12> and <fact14>elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine levels</fact14> are consistent with chronic kidney disease. Additionally, the <fact15>wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra</fact15> can be a consequence of the bone disease associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism, which leads to osteitis fibrosa cystica and increased risk of fractures. The patient's medication list includes <fact5>sevelamer</fact5>, a phosphate binder used to treat hyperphosphatemia in patients with chronic kidney disease, further supporting the presence of secondary hyperparathyroidism. Therefore, the most likely explanation for these findings is {B}.

question:
A 21-year-old male presents to his primary care provider for fatigue. He reports that he graduated from college last month and returned 3 days ago from a 2 week vacation to Vietnam and Cambodia. For the past 2 days, he has developed a worsening headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists. The patient has a past medical history of asthma managed with albuterol as needed. He is sexually active with both men and women, and he uses condoms “most of the time.” On physical exam, the patient’s temperature is 102.5°F (39.2°C), blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He has tenderness to palpation over his bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints and a maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs. Tourniquet test is negative. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL
Hematocrit: 44%
Leukocyte count: 3,200/mm^3
Platelet count: 112,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl-: 104 mEq/L
K+: 4.6 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 18 mg/dL
Glucose: 87 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
AST: 106 U/L
ALT: 112 U/L
Bilirubin (total): 0.8 mg/dL
Bilirubin (conjugated): 0.3 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Chikungunya
B) Dengue fever
C) Epstein-Barr virus
D) Hepatitis A
E) Typhoid fever

Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>21-year-old male</fact1> presents with <fact2>fatigue</fact2> and has recently returned from a <fact3>2 week vacation to Vietnam and Cambodia</fact3>, where he may have been exposed to various infectious diseases. His symptoms of <fact5>worsening headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists</fact5> for the past <fact4>2 days</fact4> are consistent with a viral infection. The presence of <fact13>tenderness to palpation over his bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints</fact13> and a <fact14>maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs</fact14> further supports this. Among the options provided, Chikungunya (A) is a mosquito-borne viral disease that is prevalent in Southeast Asia and is characterized by fever, joint pain, and rash, which aligns with the patient's symptoms and travel history. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of left knee pain as well as stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes. The pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs. There is no history of trauma. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Her mother died of metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago, at the age of 65 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin. Over the past 2 months, she has been taking over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31.8 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line; there is crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension. Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee?
A) Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray
B) Calcification of synovia and cartilage on ultrasound
C) Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray
D) Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
E) Fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound
answer:

Examination of the <fact16>left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line</fact16>; there is <fact17>crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension</fact17>. <fact18>Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL</fact18> and <fact19>erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h</fact19>. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the <fact20>left knee</fact20>?
A) Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray
B) Calcification of synovia and cartilage on ultrasound
C) Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray
D) Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
E) Fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound

Answer: 
Given the patient's <fact2>3-month history of left knee pain</fact2> and <fact3>stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes</fact3>, along with the <fact4>pain being worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs</fact4>, and the absence of <fact5>trauma</fact5>, the presentation is suggestive of osteoarthritis. The presence of <fact16>tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line</fact16>, <fact17>crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension</fact17>, and the patient's <fact12>weight and BMI</fact12> further support this diagnosis. Osteoarthritis is characterized by the formation of osteophytes and joint-space narrowing, which would be visible on x-ray. Therefore, the most likely finding on imaging of the <fact20>left knee</fact20> is {A}.

question:
Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?
A) A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
B) A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
C) A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
D) A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
E) A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (<fact1>HIF-1a</fact1>) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular <fact2>hypoxia</fact2>. In <fact3>normoxia</fact3>, von Hippel-Lindau (<fact4>VHL</fact4>) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1>, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by <fact4>VHL</fact4> is inhibited under <fact2>hypoxic</fact2> conditions, allowing <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> to escape degradation, dimerize with <fact5>HIF-1ß</fact5>, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of <fact6>hypoxic response elements</fact6>, leading to <fact7>angiogenesis</fact7>. Renal cell carcinoma (<fact8>RCC</fact8>) can mimic the <fact2>hypoxic</fact2> state to promote <fact7>angiogenesis</fact7> by inhibiting <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> hydroxylation, even in the absence of <fact2>hypoxia</fact2>. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> in <fact8>RCC</fact8> under <fact3>normoxic</fact3> conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?

Answer: 
Considering the experiment's goal is to detect <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> in <fact8>RCC</fact8> under <fact3>normoxic</fact3> conditions, and knowing that <fact8>RCC</fact8> can mimic the <fact2>hypoxic</fact2> state to promote <fact7>angiogenesis</fact7> by inhibiting <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> hydroxylation, we can infer that the level of <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> will be increased in <fact8>RCC</fact8> even under <fact3>normoxic</fact3> conditions. Since the question asks about the comparison to a <fact3>normoxic control cell</fact3>, we are looking for an answer that reflects an increase in <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> in <fact8>RCC</fact8> compared to a normal cell under the same conditions. The correct answer must involve a technique that can detect proteins, as <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> is a protein. Therefore, the answer is {E} A Western blot will show increased <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> compared to a <fact3>normoxic</fact3> control.

question:
A 3-week-old newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often spits up or refuses to eat. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) CT scan of the abdomen
B) Transabdominal ultrasonography
C) Barium enema
D) Anorectal manometry
E) Rectal suction biopsy
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>3-week-old newborn</fact1> is brought to the physician by his parents because of <fact2>poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting</fact2> over the past week. The <fact3>vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange</fact3>. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often <fact4>spits up or refuses to eat</fact4>. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at <fact5>50 hours of life</fact5>. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the <fact6>50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference</fact6>. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is <fact7>36.9°C (98.4°F)</fact7>, pulse is <fact8>140/min</fact8>, respirations are <fact9>40/min</fact9>, and blood pressure is <fact10>90/60 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination shows that the patient has <fact11>small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally</fact11>. The abdomen is <fact12>distended</fact12>. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an <fact13>explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum</fact13>. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of <fact14>dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air</fact14>. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting</fact2> with <fact3>greenish vomitus</fact3>, along with the <fact12>distended abdomen</fact12> and the <fact13>explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum</fact13> during the rectal exam, these findings suggest an intestinal obstruction. The x-ray showing a <fact14>section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air</fact14> further supports this diagnosis. Among the options provided, a <fact15>barium enema</fact15> would be the most likely to confirm the diagnosis by visualizing the intestinal obstruction and any potential anatomical abnormalities. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A mother brings her 18-year-old daughter to your office because she has not menstruated yet. They recently immigrated from another country, and do not have any previous medical records. The adolescent girl looks relatively short, but otherwise looks healthy. She has no complaints except for mild intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past year.
