He has responded well to etoposide and cisplatin with plans to undergo radiation therapy. However, he reports that he recently developed multiple “spots” all over his body. He denies any overt bleeding from his gums or joint swelling. His past medical history is notable for iron deficiency anemia, osteoarthritis, and paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton syndrome. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, a rash is noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities.

Results from a complete blood count are shown below:
Hemoglobin: 11.9 mg/dl
Hematocrit: 35%
Leukocyte count: 5,000/mm^3
Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3

The oncologist would like to continue chemotherapy but is concerned that the above results will limit the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen. A recombinant version of which of the following is most appropriate in this patient?
A) Interleukin 2
B) Interleukin 8
C) Interleukin 11
D) Erythropoietin
E) Granulocyte colony stimulating factor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>69-year-old male</fact1> with a history of <fact2>metastatic small cell lung carcinoma</fact2> on chemotherapy presents to his oncologist for a follow-up visit. He has responded well to <fact3>etoposide and cisplatin</fact3> with plans to undergo radiation therapy. However, he reports that he recently developed multiple “spots” all over his body. He denies any overt bleeding from his gums or joint swelling. His past medical history is notable for <fact4>iron deficiency anemia</fact4>, osteoarthritis, and paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton syndrome. He has a <fact5>40 pack-year smoking history</fact5>. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, a rash is noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities.

Results from a complete blood count are shown below:
<fact6>Hemoglobin: 11.9 mg/dl</fact6>
<fact7>Hematocrit: 35%</fact7>
<fact8>Leukocyte count: 5,000/mm^3</fact8>
<fact9>Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3</fact9>

The oncologist would like to continue chemotherapy but is concerned that the above results will limit the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen. A recombinant version of which of the following is most appropriate in this patient?
A) Interleukin 2
B) Interleukin 8
C) Interleukin 11
D) Erythropoietin
E) Granulocyte colony stimulating factor

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>metastatic small cell lung carcinoma</fact2> and current chemotherapy regimen of <fact3>etoposide and cisplatin</fact3>, along with the laboratory results showing a low <fact9>platelet count of 20,000/mm^3</fact9> and <fact8>leukocyte count of 5,000/mm^3</fact8>, it is essential to address the issue of thrombocytopenia and leukopenia to continue chemotherapy effectively. The recombinant version of Granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) is most appropriate in this patient as it stimulates the production of white blood cells, helping to mitigate the effects of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia and thrombocytopenia. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 38-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, obesity, and hyperlipidemia presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of new bilateral blisters on her hands. She says that she first noticed these blisters shortly after returning from a weekend trip to the beach two weeks prior. She denies any fevers, joint pains, or other skin rash during this period. The patient works in the adult entertainment industry. On examination, there are multiple flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands with hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation. In addition, increased hair growth is noted on the bilateral malar cheeks. Her temperature is 99.1° F (37.3° C), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 130/87 mmHg, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Her laboratory results are:

Serum:
Na+: 140 mEq/L
K+: 4.5 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 21 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Glucose: 104 mg/dL

Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm^3
Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL
Platelets: 400,000/mm^3

Anti-nuclear antibody titer 1:320

Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
A) Anti dsDNA titers
B) C-reactive protein
C) Anti-hemidesmosome titers
D) Urine porphyrin levels
E) Tzanck smear
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> with a history of <fact2>systemic lupus erythematosus, obesity, and hyperlipidemia</fact2> presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of <fact3>new bilateral blisters on her hands</fact3>. She says that she first noticed these blisters shortly after returning from a weekend trip to the beach two weeks prior. She denies any <fact4>fevers, joint pains, or other skin rash</fact4> during this period. The patient works in the <fact5>adult entertainment industry</fact5>. On examination, there are multiple <fact6>flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands</fact6> with <fact7>hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation</fact7>. In addition, <fact8>increased hair growth</fact8> is noted on the bilateral malar cheeks. Her temperature is <fact9>99.1° F (37.3° C)</fact9>, pulse is <fact10>95/min</fact10>, blood pressure is <fact11>130/87 mmHg</fact11>, respirations are <fact12>13/min</fact12>, and oxygen saturation is <fact13>98% on room air</fact13>. Her laboratory results are:

Serum:
<fact14>Na+: 140 mEq/L</fact14>
<fact15>K+: 4.5 mEq/L</fact15>
<fact16>Cl-: 100 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>HCO3-: 21 mEq/L</fact17>
<fact18>BUN: 20 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Glucose: 104 mg/dL</fact20>

<fact21>Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm^3</fact21>
<fact22>Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL</fact22>
<fact23>Platelets: 400,000/mm^3</fact23>

<fact24>Anti-nuclear antibody titer 1:320</fact24>

Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation with <fact3>new bilateral blisters on her hands</fact3> and <fact6>flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands</fact6> with <fact7>hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation</fact7>, along with <fact8>increased hair growth</fact8> on the bilateral malar cheeks, these symptoms are suggestive of porphyria cutanea tarda, a condition associated with blistering skin lesions and hypertrichosis. The fact that she works in the <fact5>adult entertainment industry</fact5> and recently spent time at the beach could indicate exposure to triggers such as sunlight or hepatitis C, which are known to precipitate the condition. Furthermore, the patient's laboratory results, including a normal <fact14>Na+</fact14>, <fact15>K+</fact15>, <fact16>Cl-</fact16>, <fact17>HCO3-</fact17>, <fact18>BUN</fact18>, <fact19>Creatinine</fact19>, and <fact20>Glucose</fact20>, along with a normal <fact21>Leukocyte count</fact21>, <fact22>Hemoglobin</fact22>, and <fact23>Platelets</fact23>, do not point towards a systemic infection or other acute conditions. The elevated <fact24>Anti-nuclear antibody titer</fact24> could be related to her history of <fact2>systemic lupus erythematosus</fact2>, but it is not directly relevant to the current skin symptoms. Given these considerations, the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis would be to measure <fact25>urine porphyrin levels</fact25>, as porphyria cutanea tarda is characterized by a specific pattern of porphyrin abnormalities. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day. His stools are a yellow color, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and he can track an object with his eyes to the midline. His hands remain fisted 50% of the time.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun taking independent steps at home. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?
A) Ages 1 month, 4 months, and 9 months
B) Ages 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months
C) Ages 2 months, 4 months, and 12 months
D) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 9 months
E) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be <fact1>breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day</fact1>. His <fact2>stools are a yellow color</fact2>, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can <fact3>lift his head and chest when in the prone position</fact3>, and he can <fact4>track an object with his eyes to the midline</fact4>. His <fact5>hands remain fisted 50% of the time</fact5>.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can <fact6>roll from supine to prone</fact6> and can <fact7>transfer her rattle from hand to hand</fact7>. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to <fact8>explore the world around him</fact8>. He has begun taking <fact9>independent steps at home</fact9>. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?

A) Ages 1 month, 4 months, and 9 months
B) Ages 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months
C) Ages 2 months, 4 months, and 12 months
D) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 9 months
E) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months

Answer: Considering the developmental milestones achieved by each child, we can estimate their respective ages. The first child is <fact1>breastfeeding well</fact1>, has <fact2>yellow stools</fact2>, can <fact3>lift his head and chest</fact3>, and <fact4>track objects with his eyes</fact4>, but his <fact5>hands remain fisted 50% of the time</fact5>, which is consistent with a 2-month-old child. The second child can <fact6>roll from supine to prone</fact6> and <fact7>transfer objects from hand to hand</fact7>, indicating an age of around 6 months. The third child is <fact8>exploring the world</fact8> and has begun taking <fact9>independent steps</fact9>, which is typical of a 12-month-old child. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy born by cesarean delivery is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B. The mother made it to all of her prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of folic acid since conception. She gave up smoking when she discovered she was pregnant. The infant’s heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 48/min, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg. APGAR testing exhibits a score of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The head is normocephalic. No neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine. There is strong flexion in all 4 extremities. Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact. Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities. Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child?
Hepatitis B serology
HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
IgM HBc negative
Total anti-HBc positive
Anti-HBs negative
Anti-HBc negative
HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL
Alanine transferase normal
A) Administer hepatitis B vaccine
B) Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG)
C) Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG
D) Check hepatitis B serology
E) Check liver enzymes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy</fact1> born by <fact2>cesarean delivery</fact2> is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a <fact3>gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B</fact3>. The mother made it to all of her <fact4>prenatal appointments</fact4> and took the recommended dose of <fact5>folic acid since conception</fact5>. She gave up <fact6>smoking when she discovered she was pregnant</fact6>. The infant’s <fact7>heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 48/min, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg</fact7>. <fact8>APGAR testing exhibits a score of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively</fact8>. The head is <fact9>normocephalic</fact9>. No <fact10>neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine</fact10>. There is <fact11>strong flexion in all 4 extremities</fact11>. <fact12>Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact</fact12>. <fact13>Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities</fact13>. Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child?

Answer: C) Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG

Explanation: Considering the child was born to a <fact3>gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B</fact3>, the risk of hepatitis B transmission to the newborn is high. The mother's adherence to <fact4>prenatal appointments</fact4> and taking the recommended dose of <fact5>folic acid since conception</fact5> indicate proper prenatal care, but the key factor here is the mother's hepatitis B status. To prevent hepatitis B transmission to the newborn, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend administering both hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 12 hours of birth if the mother is hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positive. Although the mother's HBsAg status is not explicitly mentioned in the question, the fact that she has "known hepatitis B" implies that she is likely HBsAg positive. Therefore, the best course of action for the newborn child is to administer both hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG to prevent hepatitis B transmission.

question:
An elderly man presents to his physician with complaints of difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling which began 2 months ago. His breathlessness worsens while walking, climbing the stairs, and lying flat on his back. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg. On examination, he has mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema is evident on the lower third of his legs. His respiratory rate is 33/min, SpO2 is 93% in room air, and coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases. On auscultation, the P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space, and an S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?
A) Decrease in the slope of the pacemaker potential
B) Decrease in transmembrane sodium gradient
C) Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels
D) Inhibition of aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption
E) Reduction in myocardial contractility
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>elderly man</fact1> presents to his physician with complaints of <fact2>difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling</fact2> which began <fact3>2 months ago</fact3>. His <fact4>breathlessness worsens while walking, climbing the stairs, and lying flat on his back</fact4>. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His <fact5>pulse is 98/min</fact5> and <fact6>blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg</fact6>. On examination, he has <fact7>mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema</fact7> is evident on the <fact8>lower third of his legs</fact8>. His <fact9>respiratory rate is 33/min</fact9>, <fact10>SpO2 is 93% in room air</fact10>, and <fact11>coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases</fact11>. On auscultation, the <fact12>P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact12>, and an <fact13>S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex</fact13>. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?

A) Decrease in the slope of the pacemaker potential
B) Decrease in transmembrane sodium gradient
C) Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels
D) Inhibition of aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption
E) Reduction in myocardial contractility

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling</fact2> and physical examination findings of <fact7>mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema</fact7>, he is likely experiencing heart failure. The <fact12>P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact12> and the presence of an <fact13>S3 gallop rhythm at the apex</fact13> further support this diagnosis. The medication prescribed would aim to alleviate these symptoms and improve cardiac function. Among the options provided, the most likely mechanism of action is {C} Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels. This action would help reduce venous return to the heart, thereby decreasing the preload and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure.

question:
A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz); he currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). He has Down syndrome. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A 2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass is palpated. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
A) Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray
B) A high serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration
C) Detection of rotavirus antigen on enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
D) Elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound
E) Tripple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>6-week-old male infant</fact1> is brought to the physician by his mother because of a <fact2>2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting</fact2>. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at <fact3>37 weeks' gestation</fact3> and weighed <fact4>3300 g (7 lb 4 oz)</fact4>; he currently weighs <fact5>4000 g (8 lb 13 oz)</fact5>. He has <fact6>Down syndrome</fact6>. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is <fact7>37.2°C (99°F)</fact7>, pulse is <fact8>156/min</fact8>, respirations are <fact9>32/min</fact9>, and blood pressure is <fact10>100/49 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows <fact11>upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands</fact11>. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A <fact12>2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass is palpated</fact12>. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
A) Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray
B) A high serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration
C) Detection of rotavirus antigen on enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
D) Elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound
E) Tripple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>6-week-old male infant</fact1> with a <fact2>2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting</fact2> that occurs almost immediately after most feeds, and the presence of a <fact12>2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass</fact12>, the clinical presentation suggests pyloric stenosis. Pyloric stenosis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the pylorus, which is the passage between the stomach and the small intestine. This narrowing can cause obstruction, leading to vomiting. Given the infant's symptoms and physical examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is pyloric stenosis. Therefore, further diagnostic evaluation is most likely to show an <fact12>elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound</fact12>, which is a hallmark of this condition. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 27-year-old G3P1010 makes an appointment with her gynecologist for evaluation of profuse bleeding, which began two days ago. She is 13 weeks pregnant based on the date of her last menstrual period. She is dizzy and weak, and is unable to move around the house and perform her daily tasks. Initially, she had only light spotting, but later on in the day the bleeding increased. Thus far, she has used six sanitary pads. The blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, the temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), the pulse is 125/min, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. A saline infusion is started, and blood and urine specimens are sent for analysis. On pelvic examination, the vagina contains blood and the cervical os is open. She also complains of cervical motion and adnexal tenderness on examination. An ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac low in the uterine cavity. No fetal movement or cardiac activity are observed. She is advised to rest for a couple of hours, after which the scan is repeated. Slight downward migration of the gestational sac is observed with no change in the fetal status. Which of the following is the next step in management?
A) Antibiotics
B) Bed rest and analgesics
C) Magnesium sulfate
D) Methotrexate
E) Dilation and curettage
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old G3P1010</fact1> makes an appointment with her gynecologist for evaluation of <fact2>profuse bleeding</fact2>, which began <fact3>two days ago</fact3>. She is <fact4>13 weeks pregnant</fact4> based on the date of her last menstrual period. She is <fact5>dizzy and weak</fact5>, and is unable to move around the house and perform her daily tasks. Initially, she had only <fact6>light spotting</fact6>, but later on in the day the bleeding increased. Thus far, she has used <fact7>six sanitary pads</fact7>. The <fact8>blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg</fact8>, the <fact9>temperature is 37.8°C (100°F)</fact9>, the <fact10>pulse is 125/min</fact10>, and the <fact11>respiratory rate is 14/min</fact11>. A <fact12>saline infusion is started</fact12>, and blood and urine specimens are sent for analysis. On <fact13>pelvic examination</fact13>, the vagina contains blood and the <fact14>cervical os is open</fact14>. She also complains of <fact15>cervical motion and adnexal tenderness</fact15> on examination. An <fact16>ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac low in the uterine cavity</fact16>. No <fact17>fetal movement or cardiac activity</fact17> are observed. She is advised to rest for a couple of hours, after which the scan is repeated. Slight <fact18>downward migration of the gestational sac</fact18> is observed with no change in the fetal status. Which of the following is the next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>profuse bleeding</fact2> at <fact4>13 weeks pregnant</fact4>, along with the findings of an <fact16>intrauterine gestational sac low in the uterine cavity</fact16> and no <fact17>fetal movement or cardiac activity</fact17>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing a miscarriage. The presence of an <fact14>open cervical os</fact14> and <fact18>downward migration of the gestational sac</fact18> further supports this diagnosis. Given the patient's unstable vital signs, including a <fact8>low blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg</fact8> and a <fact10>high pulse of 125/min</fact10>, immediate intervention is necessary to prevent further complications. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a dilation and curettage (D&C) to remove the products of conception and stabilize the patient's condition. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with 4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools. His mother noted bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past 3 days. On physical exam his temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He has dry mucous membranes. On abdominal exam you note diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. There are no masses, hepatosplenomegaly, and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis. Stool is guaiac positive. He receives 15mg/kg acetaminophen and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of lower extremity weakness and tingling. On repeat exam, lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Gram stain positive CSF
B) Peripheral eosinophilia
C) Xanthochromia on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
D) Increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count
E) Oligoclonal bands on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-year-old previously healthy boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools</fact2>. His mother noted <fact3>bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours</fact3>. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past <fact4>3 days</fact4>. On physical exam his <fact5>temperature is 102.2°F (39°C)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 120/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 22/min</fact8> and <fact9>O2 saturation is 99% on room air</fact9>. He has <fact10>dry mucous membranes</fact10>. On abdominal exam you note <fact11>diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding</fact11>. There are no masses, <fact12>hepatosplenomegaly, and bowel sounds are hyperactive</fact12>. Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis. Stool is <fact13>guaiac positive</fact13>. He receives <fact14>15mg/kg acetaminophen</fact14> and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of <fact15>lower extremity weakness and tingling</fact15>. On repeat exam, lower extremity strength is <fact16>3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact16>. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?

A) Gram stain positive CSF
B) Peripheral eosinophilia
C) Xanthochromia on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
D) Increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count
E) Oligoclonal bands on cerebrospinal fluid analysis

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the boy initially had symptoms of a gastrointestinal infection with <fact2>intermittent vomiting and loose stools</fact2>, <fact3>bloody stools</fact3>, and <fact5>fever</fact5>. However, the development of <fact15>lower extremity weakness and tingling</fact15> with <fact16>diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact16> suggests neurological involvement. The most likely diagnosis is Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), an autoimmune disorder often triggered by infections. A key laboratory finding in GBS is the presence of <fact17>increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count</fact17>, also known as albuminocytologic dissociation. This finding is characteristic of GBS and helps differentiate it from other neurological conditions. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue. She also reports generalized itchiness that started approximately 2 months ago. Two weeks ago, she noticed yellowing of her eyes. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She uses eyedrops for persistent dryness of the eyes. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are generalized skin excoriations. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,700/mm3
Platelet count 332,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 122 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL
Direct 2.5 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 452 U/L
AST 155 U/L
ALT 168 U/L
Hepatitis B surface antigen negative
Hepatitis B core IgM antibody negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody positive
Hepatitis C antibody negative
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows mildly increased echogenicity of the liver. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient?"
A) Inferior vena cava thrombosis
B) Cutaneous xanthomas
C) Butterfly-shaped vertebrae
D) Increased CA 19-9 levels
E) Kayser-Fleischer rings
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>57-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>3-month history of fatigue</fact2>. She also reports <fact3>generalized itchiness that started approximately 2 months ago</fact3>. Two weeks ago, she noticed <fact4>yellowing of her eyes</fact4>. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She uses eyedrops for persistent <fact5>dryness of the eyes</fact5>. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows <fact6>jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin</fact6>. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft. The liver edge is palpable <fact7>3 cm below the right costal margin</fact7>. There are generalized <fact8>skin excoriations</fact8>. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,700/mm3
Platelet count 332,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 122 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL
Direct 2.5 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 452 U/L
AST 155 U/L
ALT 168 U/L
Hepatitis B surface antigen negative
Hepatitis B core IgM antibody negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody positive
Hepatitis C antibody negative
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows mildly increased echogenicity of the liver. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient?

A) Inferior vena cava thrombosis
B) Cutaneous xanthomas
C) Butterfly-shaped vertebrae
D) Increased CA 19-9 levels
E) Kayser-Fleischer rings

Answer:

Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>3-month history of fatigue</fact2>, <fact3>generalized itchiness</fact3>, <fact4>yellowing of her eyes</fact4> (jaundice), and laboratory results showing elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT), high alkaline phosphatase, and direct hyperbilirubinemia, the most likely diagnosis is Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC). The patient's <fact5>dryness of the eyes</fact5> and <fact6>jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin</fact6> are also consistent with PBC. A common finding in patients with PBC is the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are due to copper accumulation in the cornea. Given the patient's clinical presentation and the absence of other liver disease markers (e.g., hepatitis B and C), the most likely additional finding is Kayser-Fleischer rings. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. She complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
B) Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 1
C) Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A
D) Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2B
E) Neurofibromatosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the physician with a history of <fact2>headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis</fact2>. She was diagnosed with <fact3>hypertension</fact3> in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a <fact4>diffuse thyroid swelling</fact4> for the past 4 months. She complains of <fact5>pain in the long bones of her arms and legs</fact5> for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her <fact6>pulse is 116/min</fact6>, the <fact7>blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg</fact7>, the <fact8>respiratory rate is 29/min</fact8>, and the <fact9>temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact9>. Diffuse and firm <fact10>thyromegaly</fact10> is present. Her upper extremities exhibit <fact11>fine tremors</fact11> during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal <fact12>elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines</fact12>. Serum <fact13>epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated</fact13>. <fact14>Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia</fact14> are also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis</fact2>, along with the findings of <fact10>thyromegaly</fact10>, <fact11>fine tremors</fact11>, <fact12>elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines</fact12>, and <fact13>elevated serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels</fact13>, multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome should be suspected. Among the options, MEN 2A is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma (evidenced by elevated VMA and metanephrines), and hyperparathyroidism (indicated by elevated parathormone levels). The presence of <fact14>hypercalcemia</fact14> supports the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {C}.

question:
In a study to determine the risk factors for myocardial infarction (MI) at a young age (age < 30 years), 30 young patients with the condition are recruited into the study group. Sixty similar but healthy individuals are recruited into the control group. Educational status is considered to be an important variable, as it would affect the awareness of the disease and its risk factors among the participants. Based on the level of education, 2 groups are formed: low educational status and high educational status. A chi-square test is performed to test the significance of the relationship, and an odds ratio of 2.1 was computed for the association between low education and the risk of MI, with a confidence interval of 0.9–9.7. What inference can be made on the association between young age MI and educational status from this study?
A) The association is not statistically significant, and low education is not a risk factor.
B) The association is statistically significant, but low education is not a risk factor.
C) The association is not statistically significant, but low education is a risk factor.
D) One can not comment, as the p-value is not given.
E) The association is statistically significant, and low education is a risk factor.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A study to determine the risk factors for myocardial infarction (MI) at a young age (<fact1>age < 30 years</fact1>) recruited <fact2>30 young patients</fact2> with the condition into the study group and <fact3>sixty similar but healthy individuals</fact3> into the control group. Educational status was considered an important variable, as it would affect the awareness of the disease and its risk factors among the participants. Based on the level of education, <fact4>2 groups were formed: low educational status and high educational status</fact4>. A <fact5>chi-square test</fact5> was performed to test the significance of the relationship, and an <fact6>odds ratio of 2.1</fact6> was computed for the association between low education and the risk of MI, with a <fact7>confidence interval of 0.9–9.7</fact7>. What inference can be made on the association between young age MI and educational status from this study?

Answer: 
The correct answer is A) The association is not statistically significant, and low education is not a risk factor. 

Explanation: 
The study found an <fact6>odds ratio of 2.1</fact6> for the association between low education and the risk of MI, but the <fact7>confidence interval of 0.9–9.7</fact7> crosses 1, indicating that the association is not statistically significant. In a confidence interval for an odds ratio, if the interval includes 1, it suggests that the association may be due to chance, and the result is not statistically significant. Since the association is not statistically significant, we cannot conclude that low education is a risk factor for young age MI.

question:
A 72-year-old man develops reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL three days after being hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. On admission, a complete blood count showed a hemoglobin concentration of 15.5 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3. Urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, and serum studies showed a blood glucose of 145 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis. Therapy with intravenous ketoprofen, piperacillin, and tazobactam was begun, and the patient was placed on bowel rest. He has a history of hypertension, chronic constipation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, metoprolol, and losartan. Today, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft on physical examination, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings?
A) Gastrointestinal blood loss
B) Adverse drug reaction
C) Dehydration
D) Contrast administration
E) Chronic hypertension
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>72-year-old man</fact1> develops <fact2>reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL</fact2> three days after being hospitalized for <fact3>acute diverticulitis</fact3>. On admission, a complete blood count showed a <fact4>hemoglobin concentration of 15.5 g/dL</fact4> and a <fact5>leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3</fact5>. Urinalysis showed <fact6>2+ proteinuria</fact6>, and serum studies showed a <fact7>blood glucose of 145 mg/dL</fact7> and a <fact8>creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL</fact8>. A <fact9>CT scan of the abdomen</fact9> confirmed the diagnosis. Therapy with <fact10>intravenous ketoprofen</fact10>, <fact11>piperacillin</fact11>, and <fact12>tazobactam</fact12> was begun, and the patient was placed on <fact13>bowel rest</fact13>. He has a history of <fact14>hypertension</fact14>, <fact15>chronic constipation</fact15>, and <fact16>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact16>. Prior to admission, his medications were <fact17>insulin</fact17>, <fact18>metoprolol</fact18>, and <fact19>losartan</fact19>. Today, his <fact20>temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F)</fact20>, <fact21>pulse is 97/min</fact21>, <fact22>respirations are 12/min</fact22>, and <fact23>blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg</fact23>. The abdomen is soft on physical examination, and there is <fact24>tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant</fact24>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>72-year-old man</fact1> developed <fact2>reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL</fact2> three days after being hospitalized for <fact3>acute diverticulitis</fact3> and starting therapy with <fact10>intravenous ketoprofen</fact10>, <fact11>piperacillin</fact11>, and <fact12>tazobactam</fact12>. The <fact10>intravenous ketoprofen</fact10> is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), which is known to cause renal impairment, especially in patients with pre-existing renal disease or those taking other nephrotoxic medications. Given the patient's history of <fact14>hypertension</fact14> and <fact16>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact16>, he may have had underlying renal disease, making him more susceptible to NSAID-induced renal impairment. Additionally, the patient's <fact8>creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL</fact8> on admission was within normal limits, suggesting that the renal impairment developed during his hospital stay. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings is an <fact10>adverse drug reaction</fact10> to the NSAID. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. He had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he complained that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He does not sleep well and wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He does not leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time and psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Short- and long-term memory is impaired. Attention and concentration are impaired. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentration of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference range. He is very concerned about his memory lapses. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Donepezil
B) Fluoxetine
C) Aspirin
D) Ventriculoperitoneal shunt
E) Memantine
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>78-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the physician by his daughter because of <fact2>increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks</fact2>. He had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he complained that he was unable to perform some of his <fact3>daily activities</fact3>. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He does not sleep well and wakes up <fact4>6–7 times during the night</fact4>. He does not leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has <fact5>hypertension treated with amlodipine</fact5>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows <fact6>orientation to person, place, and time and psychomotor retardation</fact6>. He has a <fact7>blunted affect</fact7>. <fact8>Short- and long-term memory is impaired</fact8>. <fact9>Attention and concentration are impaired</fact9>. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentration of <fact10>electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference range</fact10>. He is very concerned about his <fact11>memory lapses</fact11>. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Donepezil
B) Fluoxetine
C) Aspirin
D) Ventriculoperitoneal shunt
E) Memantine

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>78-year-old man</fact1> is experiencing <fact2>increasing forgetfulness</fact2> that has impacted his ability to perform <fact3>daily activities</fact3>, along with <fact8>short- and long-term memory impairment</fact8> and <fact9>impaired attention and concentration</fact9>. These symptoms are indicative of a cognitive disorder, specifically dementia. Given that his <fact10>electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 levels</fact10> are within normal limits, reversible causes of dementia have been ruled out. Among the provided options, Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor commonly used to treat the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease, the most common form of dementia. Therefore, the most appropriate treatment for this patient is {A}.

question:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up vaccination 1 week after being bitten by a rodent while camping. She received appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis in the emergency department and has already received 2 doses of the rabies vaccine. The same physician has been managing the post-exposure care regimen. After the physician administers the third dose of the rabies vaccine, the patient asks him if he would like to join her for a movie and dinner. The physician is interested in going on a date with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction for the physician to have to the patient's invitation?
A) Inform the patient that romantic relationships with current patients are unethical.
B) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her because her case is uncomplicated and does not require decision-making on his part.
C) Inform the patient that dating her will never be appropriate even once the physician-patient relationship has been terminated.
D) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her, but that she will have to transfer her care to a different physician.
E) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her because she no longer requires his service as a physician.
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>26-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the <fact2>physician for a follow-up vaccination</fact2> <fact3>1 week after being bitten by a rodent while camping</fact3>. She <fact4>received appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis in the emergency department</fact4> and has already <fact5>received 2 doses of the rabies vaccine</fact5>. The same <fact6>physician has been managing the post-exposure care regimen</fact6>. After the <fact6>physician</fact6> administers the <fact7>third dose of the rabies vaccine</fact7>, the <fact1>patient</fact1> asks him if he would like to join her for a <fact8>movie and dinner</fact8>. The <fact6>physician</fact6> is <fact9>interested in going on a date with her</fact9>. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction for the <fact6>physician</fact6> to have to the <fact1>patient's</fact1> invitation?

Answer: 
The most appropriate reaction for the <fact6>physician</fact6> to have to the <fact1>patient's</fact1> invitation is to inform the <fact1>patient</fact1> that romantic relationships with current <fact1>patients</fact1> are unethical. This is because the <fact6>physician</fact6> is still actively managing the <fact1>patient's</fact1> care, as evidenced by the administration of the <fact7>third dose of the rabies vaccine</fact7>, and the <fact1>patient</fact1> is still under his care. The <fact6>physician's</fact6> interest in going on a date with the <fact1>patient</fact1> (<fact9>interested in going on a date with her</fact9>) does not supersede the ethical considerations of maintaining a professional relationship with a current <fact1>patient</fact1>. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a neck mass. He first noticed a firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck approximately 4 months ago. The mass is painless and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed occasional fatigue and has gained 10 pounds in the past 4 months despite no change in his diet or exercise frequency. His past medical history is notable for gout for which he takes allopurinol. He denies any prior thyroid disorder. He runs 4 times per week and eats a balanced diet of mostly fruits and vegetables. He does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine with dinner. His family history is notable for medullary thyroid cancer in his maternal uncle. His temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 127/72 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 19/min. On exam, he has a firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid. A biopsy of this patient's lesion would most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?
A) Diffuse infiltrate of lymphoid cells destroying thyroid follicles
B) Dense fibroinflammatory infiltrate
C) Papillary projections with dystrophically calcified regions
D) Pleomorphic undifferentiated infiltrative cells with necrosis
E) Stromal amyloid deposition
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with a <fact2>neck mass</fact2>. He first noticed a <fact3>firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck</fact3> approximately <fact4>4 months ago</fact4>. The mass is <fact5>painless</fact5> and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed <fact6>occasional fatigue</fact6> and has <fact7>gained 10 pounds in the past 4 months</fact7> despite no change in his diet or exercise frequency. His past medical history is notable for <fact8>gout</fact8> for which he takes <fact9>allopurinol</fact9>. He denies any prior <fact10>thyroid disorder</fact10>. He runs <fact11>4 times per week</fact11> and eats a <fact12>balanced diet of mostly fruits and vegetables</fact12>. He does not <fact13>smoke</fact13> and drinks a <fact14>glass of wine with dinner</fact14>. His family history is notable for <fact15>medullary thyroid cancer in his maternal uncle</fact15>. His temperature is <fact16>97.8°F (36.6°C)</fact16>, blood pressure is <fact17>127/72 mmHg</fact17>, pulse is <fact18>87/min</fact18>, and respirations are <fact19>19/min</fact19>. On exam, he has a <fact20>firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid</fact20>. A biopsy of this patient's lesion would most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, including the <fact3>firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck</fact3> that is <fact5>painless</fact5> and has not increased in size, along with <fact6>occasional fatigue</fact6> and <fact7>weight gain</fact7> despite no change in diet or exercise, a thyroid issue is suspected. The patient's family history of <fact15>medullary thyroid cancer</fact15> is also a significant risk factor. The physical exam finding of a <fact20>firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid</fact20> is particularly concerning for medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), which is known to be associated with familial syndromes and can present with a hard, painless thyroid mass. Among the options provided, choice E describes <fact21>stromal amyloid deposition</fact21>, which is a characteristic histopathological feature of medullary thyroid carcinoma. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 5-year-old female presents to the pediatrician for a routine office visit. The patient is in kindergarten and doing well in school. She is learning to read and is able to write her first name. Her teacher has no concerns. The patient’s mother is concerned that the patient is a picky eater and often returns home from school with most of her packed lunch uneaten. The patient’s past medical history is significant for moderate persistent asthma, which has required three separate week-long courses of prednisone over the last year and recently diagnosed myopia. The patient’s mother is 5’7”, and the patient’s father is 5’10”. The patient’s weight and height are in the 55th and 5th percentile, respectively, which is consistent with her growth curve. On physical exam, the patient has a low hairline and a broad chest. Her lungs are clear with a mild expiratory wheeze. The patient’s abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. She has Tanner stage I breast development and pubic hair.

This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
A) Absent Barr bodies on buccal smear
B) Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level
C) Elevated serum TSH level
D) Low serum ACTH level
E) Mass in the sella turcica
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>5-year-old female</fact1> presents to the pediatrician for a routine office visit. The patient is in kindergarten and doing well in school. She is learning to read and is able to write her first name. Her teacher has no concerns. The patient’s mother is concerned that the patient is a <fact2>picky eater</fact2> and often returns home from school with most of her packed lunch uneaten. The patient’s past medical history is significant for <fact3>moderate persistent asthma</fact3>, which has required three separate week-long courses of prednisone over the last year and recently diagnosed <fact4>myopia</fact4>. The patient’s mother is <fact5>5’7”</fact5>, and the patient’s father is <fact6>5’10”</fact6>. The patient’s weight and height are in the <fact7>55th and 5th percentile</fact7>, respectively, which is consistent with her growth curve. On physical exam, the patient has a <fact8>low hairline</fact8> and a <fact9> broad chest</fact9>. Her lungs are clear with a mild expiratory wheeze. The patient’s abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. She has <fact10>Tanner stage I breast development and pubic hair</fact10>.

This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?

Answer: B) Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level. This choice is the most likely because the patient's growth pattern, with a height in the 5th percentile, suggests a possible issue with bone growth. Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase is often seen in conditions affecting bone growth, such as Turner syndrome, which is also consistent with the patient's physical exam findings, including a low hairline (fact8) and broad chest (fact9).

question:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-side abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Glucose 79 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L
AST 69 U/L
ALT 100 U/L
A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Discontinue the oral contraceptive
B) Obtain hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan
C) Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
D) Administer metronidazole
E) Perform percutaneous drainage
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week</fact2>. She has been having <fact3>dull right-side abdominal pain</fact3> during this period. She has <fact4>nausea</fact4>. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has <fact5>type 1 diabetes mellitus</fact5>. Current medications include <fact6>insulin and an oral contraceptive</fact6>. She appears ill. Her <fact7>temperature is 40°C (104°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 118/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg</fact9>. On examination, the <fact10>liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender</fact10>. There are <fact11>decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact11>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
<fact12>Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL</fact12>
<fact13>Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3</fact13>
<fact14>Segmented neutrophils 74%</fact14>
<fact15>Eosinophils 1%</fact15>
<fact16>Lymphocytes 20%</fact16>
<fact17>Monocytes 5%</fact17>
Serum
<fact18>Glucose 79 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L</fact21>
<fact22>AST 69 U/L</fact22>
<fact23>ALT 100 U/L</fact23>
A <fact24>right upper quadrant ultrasound</fact24> is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week</fact2>, along with <fact3>dull right-side abdominal pain</fact3> and <fact4>nausea</fact4>, it is essential to address the potential source of her symptoms. The patient's <fact7>high temperature</fact7>, <fact8>increased pulse</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure</fact9> indicate a possible infection. The <fact10>tender liver</fact10> and <fact11>decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact11> are concerning signs that may suggest a liver abscess or another liver pathology. The laboratory results show an <fact13>elevated leukocyte count</fact13> and <fact14>increased segmented neutrophils</fact14>, which are indicative of a bacterial infection. The <fact21>high alkaline phosphatase</fact21> and <fact22>AST and ALT levels</fact22> also suggest liver involvement. Given these findings and the patient's presentation, the most appropriate next step in management is to <fact24>perform percutaneous drainage</fact24> to address the potential liver abscess. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police. He was found at a local celebration acting very strangely and was reported by other patrons of the event. The patient is very anxious and initially is hesitant to answer questions. He denies any substance use and states that he was just trying to have a good time. The patient's responses are slightly delayed and he seems to have difficulty processing his thoughts. The patient tells you he feels very anxious and asks for some medication to calm him down. The patient has a past medical history of psoriasis which is treated with topical steroids. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, you note an anxious young man. HEENT exam reveals a dry mouth and conjunctival injection. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with normal strength and sensation in his upper and lower extremities. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia, and pulmonary exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely intoxication in this patient?
A) Alcohol
B) Benzodiazepines
C) Marijuana
D) Cocaine
E) Phencyclidine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by police. He was found at a <fact2>local celebration</fact2> acting very strangely and was reported by other patrons of the event. The patient is very <fact3>anxious</fact3> and initially is hesitant to answer questions. He denies any <fact4>substance use</fact4> and states that he was just trying to have a good time. The patient's responses are slightly delayed and he seems to have difficulty processing his thoughts. The patient tells you he feels very <fact5>anxious</fact5> and asks for some medication to calm him down. The patient has a past medical history of <fact6>psoriasis</fact6> which is treated with <fact7>topical steroids</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 110/min</fact10>, <fact11>respirations are 15/min</fact11>, and <fact12>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact12>. On physical exam, you note an <fact13>anxious young man</fact13>. HEENT exam reveals a <fact14>dry mouth</fact14> and <fact15>conjunctival injection</fact15>. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with normal strength and sensation in his upper and lower extremities. Cardiac exam reveals <fact16>tachycardia</fact16>, and pulmonary exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely intoxication in this patient?
A) Alcohol
B) Benzodiazepines
C) Marijuana
D) Cocaine
E) Phencyclidine

Answer: 
Based on the patient's symptoms, including <fact3>anxiety</fact3>, <fact5>anxiety</fact5>, <fact13>anxious young man</fact13>, <fact14>dry mouth</fact14>, <fact15>conjunctival injection</fact15>, and <fact16>tachycardia</fact16>, along with the absence of any severe neurological deficits or specific signs of other substance use, the most likely intoxication in this patient is Marijuana (C).

question:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been feeling very stressed over the past several months. During this period, she has found it difficult to relax. She states that her head is full of worries. She works at an accountant's office and reports difficulty in concentrating on her work. She has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation and reports feeling more tired than usual. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. The patient states that in order to deal with her stress, she goes shopping. While shopping, she steals small trivial items and feels immediately relieved thereafter. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of shame and guilt about her actions. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop shoplifting. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Administration of lithium
B) Interpersonal therapy
C) Psychodynamic psychotherapy
D) Cognitive behavioral therapy
E) Motivational interviewing
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because she has been feeling very <fact2>stressed</fact2> over the past several months. During this period, she has found it difficult to relax. She states that her head is full of <fact3>worries</fact3>. She works at an accountant's office and reports <fact4>difficulty in concentrating on her work</fact4>. She has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation and reports feeling more <fact5>tired than usual</fact5>. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. The patient states that in order to deal with her <fact2>stress</fact2>, she goes shopping. While shopping, she <fact6>steals small trivial items</fact6> and feels immediately relieved thereafter. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of <fact7>shame and guilt about her actions</fact7>. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop <fact6>shoplifting</fact6>. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling <fact8>anxious</fact8>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, she is experiencing significant <fact2>stress</fact2> and <fact8>anxiety</fact8>, which have impacted her daily life, including her work (<fact4>difficulty in concentrating on her work</fact4>) and relationships (frequent fights with her husband). Her maladaptive coping mechanism is <fact6>shoplifting</fact6>, which provides temporary relief but leads to feelings of <fact7>shame and guilt</fact7>. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in management would be to address the underlying issues contributing to her stress and anxiety, as well as her compulsive behavior. Among the options provided, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a helpful approach for addressing maladaptive thought patterns and behaviors, such as those seen in this patient. CBT can assist her in identifying and changing negative thought patterns, managing stress and anxiety, and developing healthier coping mechanisms. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 24-year-old Asian woman is admitted to the hospital at 30 weeks gestation with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain. She is gravida 2 para 0 with a history of the same complaints in her last pregnancy which ended with a stillbirth at the 31st week. Her older sister had preeclampsia in both of her pregnancies. Currently, the patient is responsive but lethargic. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 85/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and temperature 36.4°C (97.5°F). The physical examination shows jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. The patient’s laboratory findings are as follows:
Erythrocyte count 2.7 million/mm3
Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL
Hematocrit 0.56
Reticulocyte count 1.1%
Leukocyte count 8,300/mm3
Thrombocyte count 190,000/mm3
Total bilirubin 5.3 mg/dL (91 µmol/L)
Conjugated bilirubin 4.2 mg/dL (72 µmol/L)
Alanine Transaminase (ALT) 101 U/L
Aspartate Transaminase (AST) 99 U/L
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL (80 µmol/L)
Which of the following factors is a risk factor for this patient’s condition?
A) The patient’s age
B) The patient’s race
C) Nulliparity
D) History in the previous pregnancy
E) History of preeclampsia in a sibling
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>24-year-old Asian woman</fact1> is admitted to the hospital at <fact2>30 weeks gestation</fact2> with <fact3>nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain</fact3>. She is <fact4>gravida 2 para 0</fact4> with a <fact5>history of the same complaints in her last pregnancy</fact5> which ended with a <fact6>stillbirth at the 31st week</fact6>. Her <fact7>older sister had preeclampsia in both of her pregnancies</fact7>. Currently, the patient is responsive but lethargic. The vital signs are as follows: <fact8>blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg</fact8>, <fact9>heart rate 85/min</fact9>, <fact10>respiratory rate 15/min</fact10>, and <fact11>temperature 36.4°C (97.5°F)</fact11>. The physical examination shows <fact12>jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities</fact12>. The patient’s laboratory findings are as follows:
<fact13>Erythrocyte count 2.7 million/mm3</fact13>
<fact14>Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Hematocrit 0.56</fact15>
<fact16>Reticulocyte count 1.1%</fact16>
<fact17>Leukocyte count 8,300/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Thrombocyte count 190,000/mm3</fact18>
<fact19>Total bilirubin 5.3 mg/dL (91 µmol/L)</fact19>
<fact20>Conjugated bilirubin 4.2 mg/dL (72 µmol/L)</fact20>
<fact21>Alanine Transaminase (ALT) 101 U/L</fact21>
<fact22>Aspartate Transaminase (AST) 99 U/L</fact22>
<fact23>Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL (80 µmol/L)</fact23>
Which of the following factors is a risk factor for this patient’s condition?
A) The patient’s age
B) The patient’s race
C) Nulliparity
D) History in the previous pregnancy
E) History of preeclampsia in a sibling

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact3>nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain</fact3> at <fact2>30 weeks gestation</fact2>, along with laboratory findings indicating liver dysfunction (<fact21>ALT 101 U/L</fact21> and <fact22>AST 99 U/L</fact22>), and a history of a similar condition in a previous pregnancy that ended in <fact6>stillbirth at the 31st week</fact6>, the most likely diagnosis is acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP). AFLP is a rare but serious condition that typically occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy and is associated with significant maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.

Among the provided options, the correct answer is {D} History in the previous pregnancy. This is because AFLP tends to recur in subsequent pregnancies, and the patient's history of a similar condition in her last pregnancy, which ended in stillbirth, is a significant risk factor for the current condition.

While nulliparity ({C}) is also a risk factor for AFLP, the patient's history of a previous pregnancy with similar complaints ({D}) is more directly relevant to her current condition. The patient's age ({A}), race ({B}), and the history of preeclampsia in a sibling ({E}) are not directly related to the risk of AFLP.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her physician with a four month history of fatigue and weakness. The weakness has been progressive to the point where she cannot climb stairs and stand from a sitting position. She has only had one menstrual period in the last four months and has never been pregnant. She smokes a pack of cigarettes every day and does not take any medications. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min. She is obese with a significant pannus. Abdominal striae are present. Her laboratory workup is notable for the following:

Serum:
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
K+: 3.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 314 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL
AST: 9 U/L
ALT: 8 U/L
24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)
Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)
Serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH) 2 pg/mL (> 5 pg/mL)

A 48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial shows that her serum cortisol levels do not decrease. What is the best next step in management?
A) MRI of the adrenal glands
B) MRI of the chest
C) MRI of the pituitary gland
D) Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
E) Inferior petrosal sinus sampling
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her physician with a <fact2>four month history of fatigue and weakness</fact2>. The weakness has been progressive to the point where she cannot climb stairs and stand from a sitting position. She has only had one menstrual period in the last four months and has never been pregnant. She <fact3>smokes a pack of cigarettes every day</fact3> and does not take any medications. Her <fact4>temperature is 98°F (36.7°C)</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 70/min</fact6>, and <fact7>respirations are 15/min</fact7>. She is obese with a significant pannus. Abdominal striae are present. Her laboratory workup is notable for the following:

<fact8>Serum:</fact8>
<fact9>Na+: 142 mEq/L</fact9>
<fact10>Cl-: 102 mEq/L</fact10>
<fact11>K+: 3.9 mEq/L</fact11>
<fact12>HCO3-: 25 mEq/L</fact12>
<fact13>BUN: 20 mg/dL</fact13>
<fact14>Glucose: 314 mg/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL</fact15>
<fact16>Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL</fact16>
<fact17>AST: 9 U/L</fact17>
<fact18>ALT: 8 U/L</fact18>
<fact19>24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)</fact19>
<fact20>Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)</fact20>
<fact21>Serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH) 2 pg/mL (> 5 pg/mL)</fact21>

A <fact22>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact22> shows that her serum cortisol levels do not decrease. What is the best next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>four month history of fatigue and weakness</fact2>, obesity, and abdominal striae, along with laboratory results showing elevated <fact19>24-hour urinary cortisol</fact19> and <fact20>serum cortisol</fact20> levels, and a low <fact21>serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH)</fact21> level, it is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome due to an adrenal cause. The failure of the <fact22>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact22> to decrease serum cortisol levels further supports this diagnosis. The best next step in management would be to directly visualize the adrenal glands to identify any abnormalities such as adenomas or hyperplasia. Therefore, the best next step is {A} MRI of the adrenal glands.

question:
A 22-year-old man presents to a psychiatrist complaining of mood fluctuations. He is accompanied by his mother who reports that the patient recently experienced a 5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy. The patient admits to spending $2,000 of his parent’s money, without asking, on a down payment for a motorcycle. The episode resolved after 5 days, at which point the patient felt guilty and upset. The patient’s medical history is notable for multiple month-long episodes in the past 2 years of feeling sad, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in his hobbies, and feeling constantly tired and guilty. The patient has a history of severe meningoencephalitis at the age of 17 requiring four days in the intensive care unit. During that episode, he reported seeing monkeys in his hospital room. On exam, he is a well-appearing, cooperative male in no acute distress. He is alert and oriented with a normal affect. He states that he feels sad and guilty about what happens. He denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Bipolar I disorder
B) Bipolar II disorder
C) Cyclothymic disorder
D) Persistent depressive disorder
E) Schizoaffective disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old man</fact1> presents to a psychiatrist complaining of <fact2>mood fluctuations</fact2>. He is accompanied by his mother who reports that the patient recently experienced a <fact3>5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy</fact3>. The patient admits to spending <fact4>$2,000 of his parent’s money, without asking, on a down payment for a motorcycle</fact4>. The episode resolved after <fact5>5 days</fact5>, at which point the patient felt <fact6>guilty and upset</fact6>. The patient’s medical history is notable for <fact7>multiple month-long episodes in the past 2 years of feeling sad, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in his hobbies, and feeling constantly tired and guilty</fact7>. The patient has a history of <fact8>severe meningoencephalitis at the age of 17 requiring four days in the intensive care unit</fact8>. During that episode, he reported <fact9>seeing monkeys in his hospital room</fact9>. On exam, he is a <fact10>well-appearing, cooperative male in no acute distress</fact10>. He is <fact11>alert and oriented with a normal affect</fact11>. He states that he feels <fact12>sad and guilty about what happens</fact12>. He denies <fact13>suicidal ideation</fact13>. 

Answer: 
Based on the patient's presentation of <fact3>a 5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy</fact3>, spending <fact4>$2,000 of his parent’s money, without asking, on a down payment for a motorcycle</fact4>, and feeling <fact6>guilty and upset</fact6> afterward, it suggests a manic episode. Additionally, his medical history of <fact7>multiple month-long episodes in the past 2 years of feeling sad, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in his hobbies, and feeling constantly tired and guilty</fact7> indicates depressive episodes. These episodes of mania and depression are characteristic of bipolar disorder. Given that the patient experienced at least one manic episode (<fact3>5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy</fact3>) and multiple depressive episodes (<fact7>multiple month-long episodes in the past 2 years of feeling sad, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in his hobbies, and feeling constantly tired and guilty</fact7>), the most likely diagnosis is Bipolar I disorder.

question:
A 22-year-old woman from a rural area who recently discovered she was pregnant is referred for a cardiology consultation due to cyanosis, dyspnea, and a cardiac murmur revealed at the initial prenatal visit. She is gravida 1, para 0 with an estimated gestational age of 19 weeks. She says that the murmur was found in her childhood, and the doctor at that time placed her under observation only. However, she has been lost to follow-up and has not had proper follow up in years. Currently, she complains of dizziness and occasional dyspnea on exertion which has gradually increased during her pregnancy. Prior to her pregnancy, she did not have any symptoms. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 125/60 mm Hg, heart rate 81/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F). Her examination is significant for acrocyanosis and a fixed splitting of S2 and grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border. Which of the following physiological pregnancy changes is causing the change in this patient’s condition?
A) Increase in pulmonary vascular resistance
B) Increase in heart rate
C) Decrease in systemic vascular resistance
D) Increase in cardiac output
E) Increase in blood volume
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> from a rural area who recently discovered she was pregnant is referred for a cardiology consultation due to <fact2>cyanosis, dyspnea, and a cardiac murmur</fact2> revealed at the initial prenatal visit. She is <fact3>gravida 1, para 0 with an estimated gestational age of 19 weeks</fact3>. She says that the murmur was found in her childhood, and the doctor at that time placed her under observation only. However, she has been lost to follow-up and has not had proper follow up in years. Currently, she complains of <fact4>dizziness and occasional dyspnea on exertion</fact4> which has gradually increased during her pregnancy. Prior to her pregnancy, she did not have any symptoms. The vital signs are as follows: <fact5>blood pressure 125/60 mm Hg, heart rate 81/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F)</fact5>. Her examination is significant for <fact6>acrocyanosis and a fixed splitting of S2 and grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border</fact6>. Which of the following physiological pregnancy changes is causing the change in this patient’s condition?
A) Increase in pulmonary vascular resistance
B) Increase in heart rate
C) Decrease in systemic vascular resistance
D) Increase in cardiac output
E) Increase in blood volume

Answer:
